Posts.Title: Oncologist Resigned without Notice JeninMichigan JFL

Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2010 07:26AM JeninMichigan wrote: Texas I am so sorry you are hear at your young age with with your young children.    I was 41 when diagnosed with stage IV right from the start.  The previous year I had a very painful lump that was dismissed as a cyst - two times!!!    I was in shock and horror that I could have stage IV breast cancer.    I had mets to my liver and bones and am a single mom of 2 girls.    After three months on chemo, I was in remission and have remained that was now for over two years.     I too yelled at my kids and felt horrible about it.    But you are going through a lot right now and trying to embrace this diagnosis is really really hard.   Don't be too tough on yourself.      The feelings - fear, anger, anxiety, and just horror are hard to deal with.     Take it one day at a time and don't be afraid to get help and support from professionals.   I took alot of ativan and it got me through..  And for God's sake ... do not listen to statistics!!!  You are not a statistic .. you are your own person.   My oncologist refuses to give a statistic.   That is a number derived out of all breast cancers and ages of patients.   You can't possibly compare it to yourself.     Have hope!!  Enjoy and life your life in spite of this disease.  Don't spend it in fear and worry.   We are hear for you!! Jennifer

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2011 10:43AM JeninMichigan wrote: Liane Submitting those papers does not mean you are going to die in six months.   When my oncologist signed those papers for me last year, she said "now Jen, I am signing these because I want you to get some stress relief.  However, I absolutely expect you to be around one year from now and doing as well as you are today".   I was NED when she signed those and I didn't feel at all guilty or bad about turning in those accel. benefits.   We all know it is unpredictable and you can go from NED to big progression quickly.   We also know you can resolve progression or live in a stable way for many years.     Point is, you qualify for the benefits.  Take advantage of it and remove some of the other stress from your life. Sometimes we all need a huge crying session!! ((HUGS)) Jennifer

Posts.Content: May 23, 2013 07:15PM - edited May 24, 2013 11:26AM by JeninMichigan I am so very sorry for your broken heart. However you do deserve someone who truly loves you and someone who is strong enough to be your man. And please do not despair. I was in your boat and we have a similar pathology. I have been NED now for five years and for the last year and a half had been dating a pretty good guy who knew full well about my disease. I recently called it off and not him. There is much hope for your health and your love life. You deserve the very best. And while you are going through treatment your focus should be on you and how you cope. You shouldn't have to expend energy tending to your bf's need. He should be lifting you up and strong for you instead of the other way around. Tough times tell just how solid your relationship really is and how strong your man is (or in this case isn't). Don't settle for less just because of your diagnosis. Sending a warm hug and much hope for the future. Jennifer

Posts.Content: Oct 22, 2010 05:44AM JeninMichigan wrote: I am so sorry.    You are a wonderful sister and I know your sister needs you to be there for her right now.   Not for sympathy but just for support and encouragement    Vicki said it right that your sister would NEVER want you to go through what is happening to her.   My older sister was by my side for all my oncologist appointments and during all my chemos.   She didn't cry or wasn't upset ... she was a calming force being there with me.  We because even closer and laughed alot during those times.   She took notes and remembered things for me.   These are things you are do for your sister that make her treatments easier.   Also remember that Stage IV doesn't mean the end... it means she has a chronic disease.   My doctor said lots of people live long happy lives with chronic diseases.   Being HER2 positive is a blessing because she can be treated with drugs like Herceptin and Tykerb and they are generally easy to tolerate.    After chemo is over, she very well may continue for many many years with these drugs living a pretty normal life.   I am over 2 1/2 years cancer free after mets to my liver, bones and chest nodes.   I am just on Herceptin and life is very good.   Stay positive for your sister, cheer her on and you will be doing exactly what you need to do for her.   Nobody needs to full "get it". .. that just happens in time.   Jennifer

Posts.Content: Nov 11, 2010 02:57AM JeninMichigan wrote: Diane - what absolutely fabulous news for you!   It is hard call whether to continue the chemo once you reach this point.   I am not triple neg but Her2+.    Once I reached NED we continued the scheduled cycles of my chemo and then I went to Herceptin plus Zometa.  However, we then also through in a year of Tykerb with the Herceptin just for safety sake.    Granted, Herceptin is a pretty easy drug to tolerate I know that it still taxes my liver..    I am still NED but personally will not even think of stopping the Herceptin.     I guess it depends on what drug they want to give you and side effects you will need to deal with while on it.     You are in a good position making these decisions!! Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2010 05:48AM JeninMichigan wrote: Jennifer You have a heavy load on your shoulders and it is so normal to become overwhelmed by the enormity of it all.   Having to deal with your own disease is hard enough all by itself but when you add on the grief from losing your mother, a husband with health issues, the loss of being able to have children and then a transition out of working, it is amazing that you can hold it together at all.  The heavy load certainly makes you very sensitive to hearing about other people's good fortunes and even unsympathetic to their misfortunes.   You are not by any stretch whining.   These are the lows we go through in dealing with the bad hand dealt to us.   There is no magic fix as different things for work each of us in getting out of the funk.    Once thing for sure is that you are always welcome to unload here and are certain to find at the very least complete understanding for where you are at and usually lots of suggestions.   Holidays are stressful and they evoke all kinds of feelings that can only make it harder to deal with.   Consider the help of antidepressants or even some anti anxiety meds to help you get through it.  Sometimes it is not enough to count your blessings.  We are not wrong for wanting more from life.    Hope you are feeling a little better today and can find some joy in every day. ((((hugs))))) Jennifer

Posts.Content: May 24, 2012 03:43AM JeninMichigan wrote: Hi Middlebuck3 I am sorry for the news your mom has received. It certainly feels like a death sentence when you get it.  However, being HER2 positive is a good thing and Herceptin is very effective.   I had liver and bone mets right from the start and was treated with chemo including Herceptin at the start which took care of the 4 lesions on my liver and all of my bones mets.   I have remained NED (no evidence of disease) coming up now on 4 years.   One of my best friends had Estrogen positive b/c in both breasts.  When it returned in her liver she had a 6 CM tumor and it was HER2 positive only. She was treated with Herceptin and also was NED for five years.     I hope your mom has a similar experience.  I still get Herceptin every 3 weeks and will continue to do so indefinitely.    For many many, it is a miracle drug.    Jennifer
Posts.Title: her2 positive middlebuck3 bhd1

Posts.Content: May 25, 2012 05:33AM JeninMichigan wrote: I'll qualify my statement, providing Herceptin works for you, being HER2 can be a good thing.  Additionally there are other targeted drugs just for HER2 and more in trials.  For my friend, having her liver come back as HER2 gave her a new set of options as she already went through all the hormonals.  If it had been ER+ on the reoccurance, they told her there was likely not much more they could do for her.   No cancer is a good thing but many of your long term stage IV survivors are here because of the likes of Herceptin.  Unfortunately, there are still many who fail on Herceptin and it seems many eventually fail on it.   I'll still remain hopeful for the approval of the next drug that blocks this protein.  Jennifer

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2014 12:57PM JeninMichigan wrote: Hi Jaytee I am sorry to hear you are dealing with this once again.    I will tell you a little success story I have had with my  treatment.  I was diagnosed from the start with mets (liver, bones, chest nodes).   I did six cycles of taxotere, Carboplatin and Herceptin.  After three cycles, I had a scan and every single met had resolved.   I was NED.  Finished up my chemo and then had radiation and continued Herceptin.  My onc added a year of Tykerb just for some brain protection.    I have now been on Herceptin every 3 weeks and I get Aredia once a year now for six years and have remained NED.    I feel very blessed.  Herceptin seems to work miracles for me as long as I stay on it.  I pray for similar success for you.   Having children makes it so much more painful.   My girls were 8 and 12 when I was dx and other than saying I have breast cancer I have never shared my stage nor my prognosis with them.  I was happy in my case I did not because it would have been six years of their youth they would have feared my death.  When (hopefully) if it comes back, then  we will cross that bridge.  One day at a time is the best your can do right now.  Keep us posted on your treatment from here.  Jennifer

Posts.Title: ? about mouth sores pattih JeninMichigan

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2012 08:47PM JeninMichigan wrote: My daughter recently had a very very bad case of thrush.   My naturalist told me to use Colloidal Silver - one teaspoon straight swished for five minutes - 3 times a day.  For adults - two teaspoons.    For her, it cleared it right up.    I get still occasionally get mouth sores and it worked very well and very fast.   Worth a try.   You can get it at a Vitamin Shoppe or Health food store or I am sure on line.    And, if the sores go down into the esophagus, you can also swallow it.  They warn that long term use of it might disrupt the environment in the stomach so if you have to swallow it often you should use a probiotic/digestive enzyme.   Jennifer
Posts.Title: ? about mouth sores pattih JeninMichigan

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2009 04:14AM JeninMichigan wrote: You must take calcium every day.   All the chemo and especially zometa and/or aredia sucks the calcium right out of you.  Eating right is great but even that is not enough for most normal women let alone those fighting cancer.    I can tell you it made a huge huge different for me upping mine to 1800 mg.   My oncologist even suggested up to 2000 mg with magnesium and vitamin D.     You WILL see the difference!!! Jennifer

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2010 04:36AM JeninMichigan wrote: Hopetoheal I am so sorry your mom has this diagnosis.    I had a similiar diagnosis .. bone/liver mets right from the start.  I am 5 percent ER+ and HER+.     I had lumpectomy, 6 cycles of taxotere, carboplatin and Herceptin and Zometa.   6 weeks of rads.    After three cycles of the chemo, they did a pet scan and I was NED (no evidence of disease = no cancer).  This was June 2008.   I have continued with Herceptin and Zometa or Aredia and Tamoxifen.   I am due for another scan next week but so far have stayed cancer free.   No, there is no cure for the disease but it can be a manageable disease and your mom can live for a long time with a pretty good quality of life.    I have an 11 year old daughter so I can appreciate the fear at that age.  The next six months will be very hard for her and for your family.  Please feel free to lean on us as much as you need.    You are welcome to PM me as well. ((((hugs))))) Jennifer

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2011 07:39AM JeninMichigan wrote: Hi Jan  I didn't read all the replies so I am sorry if I repeat what already has been said.  I lost about 24 pounds when I was on Taxotere.   The first 5-7 days were awful with that garbage mouth.   I ate what I lovingly referred to as the "White Food diet" .. mashed potatoes, cream of chicken soap, baked potatoes.    After about 7 days, that nasty taste diminished and I could eat other foods.  However, during the whole time on chemo I could not eat anything that had a tomato base .. sauce, ketchup... it like fizzed in my mouth.  I couldn't drink red wine either .. same thing.    ON the metallic taste, sometimes sucking on lemon heads or lifesavers helped.   I even recall sleeping with lifesavers (butter rum) in my mouth just to get to sleep.    Also, even water tasted like metal so I could put a freezy pop in my water and it helped.     No fear, after you get off Taxotere, your taste comes back.  I gained back all that weight plus another 10!!!!  It is a great and powerful drug though!! Jennifer

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2012 05:31AM JeninMichigan wrote: I just want to add that tumor markers are not always a very good way to measure what is happening.  For some people, they are in full progression and their numbers stay normal.  Some have higher numbers with no progression.    Inflammation and infections certainly cause the numbers to rise.   Yeast will certainly cause them to rise.    Don't be upset that this test wasn't done.    My oncologists didn't take any tumor markers until last year and I only do them occasionally. She said a PET scan is the real way to know what is happening.    Don't borrow worry and stress until you know what is going on.  I know you feel horrible your mom has to go through the anxiety of the PET.  Sometimes they are just bittersweet ... lots of worry for nothing.   I hope and pray the high numbers are only the result of the other issues she has been experiencing and not cancer. Jennifer

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2010 05:10AM JeninMichigan wrote: Connie There are men out there who will love you in spite of this disease.  I have been divorced 5 years now and have cancer for the last two years (coming up on my two year cancerversary).   I am a single mum too.  I just started finally dating when it happened.  I was going out with a really nice and normal guy.   When I was diagnosed I called it off but I didn't tell him why.   I sent him a birthday text a few weeks after I finished chemo and we started talking again.   I told him what happened with me and he as me to lunch.   I remember feeling very self conscious wearing my wig.   He totally didn't care about it.   I remember ditching the wig with very very short hair uncovered and going out in public with him.   I didn't even dare go to work yet with that kind of short.  Again, he told me I was beautiful.    I ended up letting him go after a while just because he wanted something serious and I didn't.    However, moral of the story ... this disease does not prevent you from being loved.  You need to love yourself and let go.   I totally let go of my hair issues, chopped and scarred up chest and found out I was still desirable.    You won't necessarily be bald forever either.   There are lots of chemo options if you have to stay on chemo for long periods of time that do not cause hair loss.    Right now I have my hair back and am not doing any chemo except Herceptin and Aredia but I am not dating but only because I don't want to .. not because I couldn't find someone who would want me.    Have faith there are really normal men out there who would love you anyway. Jennifer
Posts.Title: Just a Little Peace of Mind meN3 tami444

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2010 11:14AM JeninMichigan wrote: Hi Connie I am sorry to hear about your complications and your very close brush with death.  That is indeed scary.   I feel that I am one of the lucky ones out of the Stage IV gang.   I had mets right from the get go to my liver, ribs, hip and chest nodes.    I went through six cycles of Taxotere, Carboplatin, Herceptin plus Zometa.   That was May - August 2008.  I followed with 6 weeks of radiation.    Of course, all of that was difficult but I managed to make it through without complications.   I remain on Herceptin, Aredia, and Tamoxifen.  I just finished a year of Tykerb.    I have been NED since June 2008 which makes me feel very very lucky.  So my qualify of life is really good.    Since finishing chemo I go about my every day life and try to keep cancer out of my head as much as possible.  I am due for a Pet scan this week and of course it is when it really hits home with me and scares me to death.  Can't wait for this week to be done!!   I know there will be a day when I am in active chemo again and so I just really try to love every minute I have that I am feeling good and not sweel on if and when.   Best of luck to you.  You are due some easier times. Jennifer
Posts.Title: Just a Little Peace of Mind meN3 tami444

Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2013 05:20AM JeninMichigan wrote: I spend quite a bit of time in denial of the disease and its reality.  Unfortunately, when you come to the boards you are painfully reminded via our common bond.   This is really the only place for me (other than my with my doctor) that I share this part of my life.   I keep it away from my family to the extent that I can.    I really think it is a give and take.   We take the support and information from our members when we need it.  It is equally important that we also give support and share information to help out our sisters.   I had a wonderful breast cancer mentor who was with me as I rapidly was restaged at the start of it.  She was stage IV and a veteran having dealt with b/c for 15 years of her life.   I couldn't have done it without her.    I think we need to pay this forward to the next one who need the support at any time of the journey.  Most of us don't have someone who "gets it".   Really unless you are in this boat, you can't really get it no matter what you think.   We need each other.  Saying goodbye is so awful but being there for that sister we lose is more important than our grief.     One final comment.... beyond the sadness of losing a sister, I meant some great family members and now see that they are thriving in spite of the lose.  For instance, when we lost Olga and she left behind a husband and two young sons.  I keep in contact with Yan and see him and their sons doing so well.     I want life to go on for my girls when the time comes for me and knowing that it does is helpful.   Jennifer

Posts.Content: May 15, 2014 06:51AM - edited May 15, 2014 06:30PM by JeninMichigan I ponder the same often.   When I look up a few definitions... Battle - "sustained fight"  or "to resist something" Fight - "violent confrontation or struggle" Survivor - "copes well with a difficult situation" or "stays alive after an event in which others have died" I understand the terminology.   I think the context in which it is used and how it is sensationalized is what really bothers me.  "oh she is heroically battling ... cancer"    I don't consider myself a warrior or anything dramatic like that.   I am not brave or inspirational.  We are only dealing with the bad hand we were dealt and trying to live as best we can for as long as we can.   On the other hand, I am battling my cancer in that I am doing anything and everything I can to stop if from progressing.  So I am indeed resisting it although fully realizing that I am not in control really what happens.  But this is my personal battle that only 2-3 people know anything about.      I will not draw my pink sword though and declare my self a surviving warrior and might well punch someone in the nose who labels me as such!! I don't know the right words really to talk about what we go through.   It isn't brave because any one of use would not sign up for this and if we could run and get away from it... every one of us would put our tails between our legs and bolt.     I just hate anyone sensationalizing the horror of cancer.  We don't want to be put on a pedastal with a crown and a sash saying "warrior" or "Miss Inspirational 2014" just use the energy and find a cure.  Jennifer

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2010 06:53AM JeninMichigan wrote: Hi Steelrose I'll tell you what happened to me.   I had a lumpectomy and after my lumpectomy we found out I had liver and bone and chest node mets.   I finished chemo and was NED.    It was time for radiation to finish my local therapy.  My oncologist told me she thought the radiation group might resist my radiation due to my stage but she wrote a very extensive letter.    I went for a consult and like you they said for my stage it wasn't worth the risk. They also told me that my cancer would come back and maybe if it didn't happen in a reasonable amount of time, they would be willing to reconsider.   My oncologist was really pissed.   So I went to the University of Michigan for radiation where they happily accepted me and I went through radiation with no problem at all.  Now, I had to drive 67 miles out of my way every day for six weeks but well worth it.   My oncologist has since told me that many of the national conferences she has attended are advocating radiation for Stage IV patients.    Her theory is you need every percentage point chance that this will not come back.   I agree.   I hope your oncologist is able to get you the radiation. Good luck Jennifer

Posts.Title: Dept. of Adding Insult to Injury Tina2 Tina2

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2015 09:59AM JeninMichigan wrote: My port was bothering me. It wasn't severe but it would hurt when I would move my arms diagonal across my chest and also certain ways I would sleep. It was working fine but just paining me. Since I was only getting Herceptin and occasionally Aredia, my onc told me I could have it replaced or just remove it and use my hand for the IV. I had it removed in 2010 and have been using my hand for IVs ever since. I have now scarred up all the veins in one hand and we are using my surgical arm which hasn't caused me any issue. I guess I still have my forearms full of veins before I get too worried about it. My port was 2 1/2 years old when I got it out. So you could get a new port in a different location or opt to go without. If you are not taking IV chemo besides the Zometa, maybe you could have a port vacation for a while.  Jen

Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2009 06:57AM JeninMichigan wrote: JoJo I am sorry for your diagnosis... truly!!   I totally appreciate where you are coming from regarding treatment.    I have two younger children who have just me so I had to do it.   I shudder to think about going through chemo again.  Although my quality of life is really good right now... it is all subject to change.    For me, my kids are the driving force... without them I would NOT do chemo again.   If you are able to afford it, I would suggest investigating the alternative route too.   It will help you all around feel better and may extend your time.   I have been heavy into lots of supplements and believe it has been a critical part of me staying cancer free for over a year now.    I will be happy to share my list of potions.   I am a single mom and it hasn't broke me financially. Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2009 10:00AM JeninMichigan wrote: I am sorry to hear your diagnosis.   You are in a great place for support and informatin.   I too would want to question the dx of mets based on a breast MRI.   I had a bone and cat scan which picked up a nodule on my lung.    I had a pet scan then that said the nodule was scarring.   There are lots of things that show up that are not cancer.  A PET scan is a better indicator of lesions and then a biopsy is the only way to know for sure.    I truly truly hope that it is some other type of spot.   If not, there are alot of treatment options.  I was Stage IV right from the start.  I have been cancer free since June 2008 (i was dx Feb 2008) and my life is very very good!!   I will say a prayer for you tonight that further tests limit this to the breast!!    You are young and it is overwhelming.  I was 41 when diagnosed with a 12 and 8 year ... it is hard not to be in a panic!!  Lean on us! Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2009 05:59AM JeninMichigan wrote: My onc feeling is that they are seeing very good results from Herceptin/Tykerb combination.  I am not in a clinical trial.   I was NED when she added Tykerb but she said she wanted to give me that extra protection for the first year after I finished chemo when reoccurance would be most likely.  She said Tykerb has not yet proven itself to be as effective as Herceptin but she is afraid that if it does document to be as good, the insurance companies might push that patients take Tykerb verus Herceptin due to costs.  She hopes this is not the case as Herceptin is a much more tolerable drug than Tykerb.  I also have heard that the more highly HER+ you are the better your respond to these drugs.   Jennifer

Posts.Content: Jul 30, 2014 07:13PM JeninMichigan wrote: Hi Sue.  Here was my treatment in a nutshell Lumpectomy 3/08 6 cycles of Taxotere, Carboplatin and Herceptin 2008 along with Zometa too (NED after 3 rounds) Fall 2007 I had 6 weeks of radiation and continued Herceptin and Zometa January 2009 - started Tamoxifen and added Tykerb continued Herceptin and switched to Aredia every 12 weeks  Did Tykerb for a years December 2010 removed ovaries continued Herceptin, tamoxifen. And Aredia 2012 switched to Arimidex.  Stopped AIs in March 2013  Currently on no hormonals but continue Herceptin every 3 weeks and Aredia just once a year I also see a Naturalist doctor and have been on a variety of herbs and supplements the entire time Jen

Posts.Content: Dec 18, 2012 03:44PM JeninMichigan wrote: It is hard to know how much emotional strain your cancer is causing.  Kids can be affected by so much and we, of course, naturally attribute it to our disease.   My daughter was acting out in 3rd grade and having crying jags at school. Come to find out it was because my mom was having her shoulder replaced and my daughter didn't want her grandma to have the surgery.   Like Fitz, I have never discussing dying from this disease.  In fact, my kids to this day do not know the stage of my cancer.   I am glad I didn't tell them because it has been nearly five years now and they would have been worrying all that time about my death.   You can cetainly though be honest with your kids and carry a positive outlook at the same time.   Counseling might be good and you might well find out the cause is something unrelated to you!! (((hugs))) Jennifer

Posts.Content: Aug 5, 2009 09:56AM JeninMichigan wrote: What a great thread. Your babies are all precious. My two daughters and I live on a small farm in rural Michigan. Two weeks ago I just rescued a second dog. He is Buddy a 3 year old Boxer. I have Hallie who I rescue just before getting diagnosed. She is now 2 1/2 and she is a Great Dane. We also have 14 cats (they are barn kitties), 1 rabbit, and 12 chickens. My 10 year old daughter is slowing talking me into getting a horse. I had horses when I was married but got rid of them with the husband. I thought it was a brilliant move on both and saved me a ton of heartache and work. I think last year when I was going through chemo my great dane, Hallie, really helped me through it. I got up and walked her nearly every single night. Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2014 09:46AM JeninMichigan wrote: Janis  I know where you are coming from.  You look at someone like Chele and she has been around a long time and was determined not to let b/c interfere with what she loved doing.  If having determination and a strong will were enough, she (and so many others) would be still here.   It is that reality check that pulls you out of the safe world of denial and gives you a sharp slap.    No matter how long we have been around and dealing with this crap, it is never long enough and you just wonder when the rug is going to be pulled out from under you.   And then the whole nesting thing starts and the back pedaling of .. wait, I need to do this or that.  It is hard to get back to living in the moment.   I find the best thing for me to do is just do a few things that are heavy on your mind.  For you, getting a trust set up and then you will feel a little better and can get back on with living.   Anxiety is so strong and it is hard to just shut it off.  I find it best to make a compromise and do a few things that helps me feel at least a little in control and then try to let it go.   I really believe it is so much about being able to control something since we can't really control our disease. I have faith in you that you will get back to your good place.  Just think how many things you have done in spite of this disease and the good times you have made by not letting it take over you.  Jen

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2014 01:27PM JeninMichigan wrote: I think too it is important to find the cause especially since you started a new drug, Zometa.   Usually your first infusion of Zometa leaves you feeling like you have the flu.   I tried several infusions of Zometa but it made me sick every time and after the sickness went away, I had every since joint in my body aching ... even down to my little toe joint.  When I took Zometa with my chemo I couldn't tell the difference because I felt so awful anyway but when I continued to get it by itself then we knew it was the real culprit of many of my bad side effects.   It made me mad because I wouldn't have felt so awful those other times.  I am on Aredia which seems to be much more agreeable with me.    I think  you would want to know at least if it was a drug side effect/issue or if it was not related to the drugs.   It would make me nervous next time around for infusion.   Hope you are feeling better!!! Jennifer

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2011 01:20PM JeninMichigan wrote: Polyana Small spots on your liver and lungs are common and usually benign.    I had a small nodule on my lung at diagnosis that showed up on the c/t scan. They ordered a pet scan about three weeks later before I started chemo and that is when they saw all my liver and bone mets but still the spot on my lung was just focal scarring.   I am not sure if the pet scan was more sensitve for me or if my cancer really went that crazy and grew three weeks time since the c/t scan.  I had four tumors on my liver with the largest measuring nearly 4 cms.   However, I had absolutely no symptoms.    Late last summer I had terrible GI issues ... very thin stools and also light in color.   My PET scan came back NED and my onc said my GI tract was somewhat wrecked from chemo.   I started digestive enzymes and a pro biotic and it has mostly taken care of the problem.   I think if i were you, I would request a PET scan if only for peace of mind.    Jennifer
Posts.Title: Call for all Liver mets patients Polyana LivingIt

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2013 01:45PM JeninMichigan wrote: This can be a very good thing. My girlfriend many years ago was faced with her third occurance of b/c and she had a huge tumor on her liver. At that time, she had been through the hormonal treatments being ER positive and the doctors gave her a very grim prognosis especially due to the size and rapid rate the tumor was taking over her liver. They took another biopsy and low and behold she was HER2 positive. After another round with Taxotere and Herceptin, she was NED and stayed that way on Herceptin for five years. It did come back to her lung and unfortunately she passed away but it had more to do with a very bad reaction to Tykerb plus Xeloda that she could not recover. But the great news is that Herceptin kept her NED and as aggressive as the cancer came it also went away pretty quick. I am her2 and have been NED now for over five years too! I think HER2 can be a very good thing!! Jennifer

Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2012 02:16PM JeninMichigan wrote: Just a suggestion of lesser importance, but if I had to do it over again, I would have taken a look at where my bra strap falls and where many of my shirts fall.  I never liked my port showing.  I don't have must chest wall fat and so mine really stuck out far.  It was hard to find clothes that covered it.   If I had to do if over, I would have moved it over closer to my shoulder about an inch and then most of my normal clothes would cover it.    However, you also don't want it to interfere with your bra strap either.    Otherwise, the port was a great convenience for getting IV chemo.   I had mine for two years with no issue at all.  I had it removed and am going without for now.  I still get herceptin every 3 weeks but my veins are holding out.   If I had to do chemo again, I would be getting another one for certain.  I didn't read the other response so I apologize if I am redundant.   I would get some Emla cream which will numb the skin.  Put is on 1 to 1 1/2 hours before they access it.  Cover it with some Saran Wrap.    You will not feel a thing when they access it.  It is a beautiful thing. Jennifer

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2010 06:03PM JeninMichigan wrote: I have had my port for almost two years now.    It is a love/hate relationship.    I love how easy it is when I got for a treatment.  However, it is UGLY.    The only place I don't have fat is on my chest and mine sticks out alot.   My surgeon ran it up into my jugular vein because I do alot of lifting and work (I live on a farm) so she didn't want to chance it getting severed running it down.  So I always look like I have a puffy kind of vein in my neck.    But it has given me no problems.   One suggestion..... if you have a style of top (tank tops or other necklines) that you favor, mark the spot that will hit the port and ask for it to be placed in that spot.  Mine is over about an inch and it is really hard to find a top that keeps it hidden especially in the summer.   Bathing suits are really hard to find one to cover that ugly button. Also, when you got to get your chemo, ask them to give you some Lidocaine cream.   Put it on about an hour before they access it and cover it with saran wrap.   You won't feel anything at all when they use it.  Getting it in isn't a big deal.   Just a little sore afterward.   Jennifer

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2013 02:06AM JeninMichigan wrote: You should contact Genentech .. the manufacturer of Herceptin.  They have a co-pay card which will pay 80% of your out of pocket expenses as it relates to the drug Herceptin.   Here is the criteria: * you must be covered by commercial/private insurance * 18 years or older * live and get treatment in the USA * Do not participate in a federal or state funded health care program * not receiving free drug assistance through Genentech the number to all is 855-692-6729.   I assume since you are HER2+, you may still be getting Herceptin.     Hope this helps.  All the other programs I have applied to - Chronic Disease Fund, Patient Advocacy Foundation, etc, have all been closed out.    Good luck Jennifer

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2009 08:40PM JeninMichigan wrote: My daughers were 9 and 13 when I was diagnosed.    I was Stage IV right from the start.   I talked to my doctor and she agreed there is no reason they need to know right now I am stage IV.   My chemo worked its magic so I am not going anywhere soon.  They know I continue to get treatments but I have stopped calling it chemo.   When they ask me if it will come back, just tell them God willing it will not.   When I was going through Chemo I encouraged them to do everything they normally did.  At their age, it was not their job to take care of me.    Just my opinion, but I am not going to worry my kids and occupy their mind with thoughts of me dying.   I don't want their childhood to be filled with that worry.   When it comes time, then worry and cry we will do.   In the meantime, I journal to them regularly and hope to God they will never have to read until they are well into adulthood.   Jennifer

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2011 07:40AM JeninMichigan wrote: One piece of advise as I was denied the first time I applied.  On my first application, we submitted copies of all of my test results and office visit notes.  Note that I have been NED for the last 2 years.  Also, my oncologist felt uncomfortable about putting 12 months or less on my application so she indicated +/- 12 months for life expectancy.   The insurance company denied me based on those two criteria.   I had another policy with a different carrier.  I talked with my oncologist and told her to look at me from a statistical point of view.   Average life expectancy is around 24 months for Stage IV.  At that time of application, it had been 29 months so statistically my life expectancy would really be less than a year.  She was good with it and in the end she said she wanted to help me with anything that would make my life easier.   I submitted just the application and physician's statements indicated 12 months or less life expectancy and this time I did not include any other notes or tests.     I had a check within 7 days!    They cannot cancel your policy.      I cannot explain the waive of relief and joy I felt getting that check.  It wasn't big enough for me to retire or anything but I paid off a whopper credit card and took my daughters on a nice vacation.    Some serious stress relief. Good luck!! Jennifer

Posts.Content: Aug 12, 2011 11:21AM JeninMichigan wrote: Let me tell you about my experience.   I had a lumpectomy and right before I started chemo they discovered my mets through a follow up pet scan.  I did chemo and all the mets resolved.  My oncologist said she absolutely wanted me to have radiation although she suspected our local radiologist might fight it due to my stage.  However, she wrote them a long letter and explained my complete response to chemo and she was ordering radiation.   They took my case to the tumor board and then they called me at my office and told me they did not feel radiation was worth the risk for me.  I asked for an explanation and he said that my cancer will come back and therefore it wasn't worth the risk.  He said if after an amount of time has passed and it hasn't returned, maybe they would reconsider.   I was really P*ssed off and so was my onc.   She then called the University of Michigan and sent me on a consult up there.  They immediately approved me and I did six weeks of radiation up at U of M.  I drove 67 miles out of my way every day for six weeks but I wanted my local therapy completed.  I had no issues at all with radiation.  If I were you, I would insist of getting every advantage you can and radiation is certainly an advantage.    (By the way, that was September 2008 and I am still NED today :-)  Jennifer

Posts.Content: Jun 23, 2013 09:44AM JeninMichigan wrote: Roberta That is quite a bit to digest in one sitting!!   I am sure at your biopsy that your doctors will be checking for any changes in your tumor status.   It is not uncommon for the tumor to change to a HER2+ status and maybe the reason for the aggressive progression especially in the brain.   I was diagnosed with HER2+ Stage 2 and after my lumpectomy they did a PET prior to starting chemo just three weeks later after having a clean C/T scan and found myself with four tumors in my liver (largest = 4 cm), all my right upper ribs, left hip and chest nodes with cancer.    I did 6 cycles of chemo and half way through a scan found me NED and now five years later I have stayed cancer free.   Brains mets adds a complication but look on this site and you will find many who have been successfully been treated with either whole brain radiation or gamma knife.   Indeed, it is a terminal disease but women are living longer than before with more targeted options.   I wouldn't prod your doctor too much for a life expectancy.   Getting the statistics on breast cancer lumps everyone together regarding of the status of their disease, age, general health, etc.    Everyone reacts differently to treatment and it is really impossible to determine at this point your life expectancy.    My doctor told me I will live a long life and I decided to go with that outlook.     Best advice I can give is to take it one step at a time and try not to swallow the whole picture at once.    It is weird but we all find out pace with this disease and you will amaze yourself at how you can handle the cards dealt to you. Please stay here with us and keep us posted. Jennifer

Posts.Content: Dec 1, 2011 08:55AM JeninMichigan wrote: Hi Krissi  Sorry about your progression to Stage IV.    I did Taxotere in 2008 and had aweseom results.  I had liver, bone and chest node mets which resolved completely after 3 cycles and I am still NED today.    It is a mighty drug.   It was tolerable for me but certainly had its share of side effects.   Everyone reacts so different.  I didn't have any neuopathy or nail issues.    I had some bad intestional issues usually 4 days after infusion.    Fatigue was a problem but bounced back the week afterward.   Yucky garbage taste in the mouth for about a week.   My eye would twitch almost constantly on it and bone pain.    Again, it was tolerable for me.  I continue to work full time through it missing only a day or two here and there. Timng was everything.  For me getting it on thursday was good so I recovered enough to go back on Mondays.   Good luck!!!!  Keep us posted how it goes. Jennifer

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2016 05:33AM JeninMichigan wrote: My oncologist told me at the onset that she absolutely believes many more women actually have mets from the start which are not diagnosed. CT/Bone scan are the standard tests for b/c before starting treatment. My mets were not picked up by these. So I proceeded to have a lumpectomy and before chemo my first onc wanted a tiny nodule on my lung checked. My surgeon fought it and said it was just a focal scar but the onc persisted. When they did the pet they found 4 tumors on my liver, most of my right ribs and left hip with mets. I also think during my lumpectomy that my grade 3 Her2+ cancer went gangbusters spreading around. Anyway, my onc said she was going to treat me just as aggressive as if I had stage 2b. All that aggressive treatment and radiation took me quickly to NED. The bonus of have mets from the start is that I keep getting treatment and so far, it hasn't come back. I often wonder if I responded so well that my cancer hasn't been able to dodge the Herpceptin. Where if I stopped Herceptin after a year, would it have had the time to redevelop and come back stronger/smarter than the drugs. I sort of agree with the 100% or 0. Cancer is so sneaky though and highly different for each person and situation. This is why I really love the MBC project and the patient focused research. Don't lump us all together. Find out why some people respond so well and study it. Interesting post Mrs. Divine! Jen
Posts.Title: Comparing Life Expectancy Statistics DivineMrsM Bliss58

Posts.Content: Aug 28, 2009 11:51AM JeninMichigan wrote: If I could swing it, I would work/volunteer part time (whatever didn't interfere with disability).  However, I am a single mom with no child support and I cannot swing it without working full time.   I do get to work out of my house two days out of five so that is a help.   As much as it tears me not to be with my girls more, it is also important for me mentally and physically to get up every day and go to work.   It got me through chemo.... made me keep moving.   I would be afraid on my days when I get depressed that I might go into a downward spiral.  Going to work doesn't' let me think too much about cancer as I usually am running like I am on fire.   As long as you keep your schedule full and can afford to do it, I would go for it in a minute.    Those years with your kids are precious and of course, we all know how precious every day/week/year is for us!! Jennifer

Posts.Content: Oct 17, 2011 05:54AM JeninMichigan wrote: Ditto all the above.   When I asked my doctor about the statistics, she said to pay no mind to statistics.  They are older information and take into account every kind of breast cancer and every kind of patients from the young to the very old.   She said breast cancer is like 15 different diseases .. you cannot really compare one to the other .. they are truly different.   She said I will live a long time and I belive her.    I had liver and bone mets from the start and have been NED (no evidence of disease) now since June 2008.   February will be my four year anniversary so I absolutely intend on making the five year mark.   No one knows how well your wife will respond to treatment.   She may live many many years with a good quality of life.    If someone is not giving you an expiration date it is because there is no way to predict such a thing at this point. Jennifer

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2011 08:20AM JeninMichigan wrote: Amontro Please wait a bit and let all of this soak in.    When I found out I had liver and bone mets I remember crying in my oncologist's office and asked her "do I need to sell my house or rehome my animals"   Should I be getting my stuff in order?  She looked at my like I was crazy ... she said ABSOLUTELY NOT!.  She told me I will live a long life.  There is an arsenal of treatments available for me.   She said it is a chronic disease like diabetes.  I will always be on treatment.  However, being Her2+ is a bonus with the options of targeted treatments.  I have been NED (no evidence of disease) now for 2 1/2 years.   In fact, today is my diagnosis anniversary - 3 years ago.    I still live on my farm with my two daughters and animals  and we carry on.    You don't have an expiration date and you can't live your life worrying about dying.   Of course, I have done some things like write a will and start a journal for my kids... but I have not made any life altering decisions other than those things that I probably should have done regardless of the cancer. Don't give up on life. Jennifer

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2010 08:48AM JeninMichigan wrote: I agree with Cathy.  I never like to hear, "you are so brave, strong, etc etc".   No ... none of us are brave or strong.   We are just going through what we have to go through.  Given a choice we wouldn't purposely do chemo.   It is a different than say being a strong parent .. you purposely make that effort but don't have to.   We all just pretty much have to do what we do to survive.   OK, sorry ... off that high horse. For me what really worked best is the people that actually showed up to help versus "call me if you need anything".  I am not the kind of person to call someone for help.   My friends stopped over with a dinner for my family, some of them mowed the lawn or shoveled snow.   I had one lady who offered to ride up with me to radiation (it was 2 hr round trip) and she was persistent and set the dates and came.    Actions speak louder than words.   My co workers all gave me wonderful movies to watch while recooperating and many of them made meals to put in the freezer.    The really good friends continued throughout chemo to do little acts of kindness which helped so much.     We do all need encouragement but let's face it, when you are going through hell sometimes what you really need is someone to run to the store for you or bring you a little something special that takes your mind off this hell.     Success stories help.   Realizing that Stage IV sisters go through treatment and then continue to carry on with life.  Some of us live a pretty decent quality of life too!! Hope this helps ... sorry I am so long winded!! Jennifer

Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2010 10:57PM JeninMichigan wrote: The receptionist at my work asked me the other day "when are you going to be done with your treatments".  I told her "NEVER".   Her jaw dropped and she said "why I never heard of something like that".  I told her my cancer has spread and I will be in treatment until it stops working and then I walked out.    I get sick of being nice about it and smiling and saying how great everything is.    I get sick of people saying, "my aunt beat it" blah blah blah.   Do they actually beat it??  Not really. You ladies are right... we are tucked away and no one sees the reality.  If they do then it is somehow our fault.    I wrote Oprah too and no rely.   Jennifer

Posts.Content: Oct 30, 2009 08:39AM JeninMichigan wrote: I had mets to several upper right ribs and left hip.  I felt absolutely no pain in either place.  Since completing treatment I have had alot of various bone pain and joint pain and muscle pain.  Especially when I get out of bed in the morning.  I have also had three pet scans six months apart that all say I am cancer free and the bone mets were completely resolved.  I don't know where all this bone, joint and muscle pain comes from.  I am on Tamoxifen, Herceptin, Tykerb and Aredia so I guess it is one or all of those causing the problem.    I think it is worthy of getting it checked out.  Hopefully it is nothing.  Somehow for me with the peace of mind that it is not cancer, I can tolerate the pain so much better.    Jennifer
Posts.Title: Bone mets- what does the pain feel like? jejarvis Tweetyb422

Posts.Content: Jun 30, 2009 12:08AM JeninMichigan wrote: What I noticed is that in the winter months, the finger splitting was worse...probably because my skin was drier.   Now the finger nails are just peeling and cracking.   I do alot with my hands as I live on a farm.   I really get upset about not being able to use my hands like I need to.    Right now I have an infected big toe nail.   I know I am being a baby about it ...but I don't want to go back to the foot doctor and get the nail treated.  It really really hurts to get those shots in your feet.   Today my dog (she is a 160# great dane) stepped on my toe and it started bleeding all over the place.  Damn it!!  Do any of your ladies have sensitivity to the sun with Tykerb?  As it has finally gotten warmer in Michigan I noticed my skin started to itch .. like a burning itch.. when I am in the sun.  I know it is not the herceptin since I was on that all last summer and did have any problems.  Of course, since I am taking care of the property all by myself I am in the sun alot so this is becoming bothersome.   I'll keep chugging along with it but I fear I am going to some nails along the way :-( Jennifer

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2013 11:56AM JeninMichigan wrote: I didn't read all the responses but everyone is different.  When I was diagnosed my girls were 12 and 8 and they had only me.   I was so upset about telling my children about my stage IV diagnosis.  My oncologist, who told me I will live a long life, said it was not necessary for me to tell my girls.  In fact, she said until you have to tell them there is no reason they need to know this level of detail about your diagnosis.   Three months later I was NED and have stayed that way now for 4 1/2 years.  I am personally glad I have never shared this level of detail of my diagnosis.  I know my girls would have spent near five years worrying and fretting about my health.  I wouldn't be able to sneeze without them worrying.   I don't think I have deceived them or lied to them.   I continue to get Herceptin every three weeks and have told my girls that is because my cancer is an aggressive kind of cancer and could come back and this is an insurance policy to help prevent.  I will also take this treatment.  Your son may need outside support handling your diagnsosis and I personally wouldn't want to limit him from getting that support.   It is a tough call and highly personal how you wish to handle it.  I truly don't think there is a right or wrong way to do it.  You need to do what works best for your family. Jennifer

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2012 08:27AM JeninMichigan wrote: aic  I am so sorry you are joining us.   In February 2008, I was diagnosed with Breast Cancer and in April following my lumpectomy, I found out I had mets to my liver, bones and chest nodes.  I was a single mom with two daughters ages 12 and 8.    After 3 cycles of chemo, my oncologists scanned me and I had no evidence of disease.  all the lesions had been resolved included the bone mets in all my right ribs and left hip.  That was June 2008 and I am still "NED" today.   I know it is a living nightmare but take one day at a time and know this is hope for living a long life.   My oncologist said to consider this a "chronic disease" like diabetes  You will be in some treatment for the rest of your life but you can live with this disease.   Stick with us!! Jennifer

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2012 12:17AM JeninMichigan wrote: Hi Janicemarie I am pretty sure the pill he is talking about is Tykerb.     It attacks the cells in a slightly different way than Herceptin although it is not as easy to tolerate.   I took Tykerb for a year with Herceptin and the main side effects were diarrhea, rash, and finger/toe nail splits and finger tip splits.    I was able to get the diarrhea under control very quickly and it wasn't a problem.  For many, it lingers and stays an issue.   You can play with the dose a bit to help.     Hopefully you might qualify for the TDM1 trial with superHerceptin.    If not, Tykerb isn't really awful.  I cannot speak for Xeloda though.     Sorry about your progression.  Hopefully you will get a plan that is easy to tolerate. Jennifer

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2011 10:19PM JeninMichigan wrote: Hi Cynthia I have been on Aredia now for two years.  I did 6 months of Zometa first but I had terrible joint pain.    The first infusion you might feel a little like you are getting the flu ... aches and maybe a low grade fever.   For me, nothing Motrin couldn't take care of and it went away within 48 hours.    My following infusions I just get some joint and bone pain in the weeks that follow but nothing terrible.   I do drink alot and they will probably give you some saline to help pass it through the kidneys.       I also had my port removed in August and have had two Aredia treatments in an IV in my hand and there was not problem at all with it.  Good luck to you.  It really is a pretty mild drug. Posts.Content: May 7, 2016 08:28PM JeninMichigan wrote: Hi JCNC I am so sorry you have to join our group and so young. I was dx at 41 with liver and bone mets from the start. I am very weakly ER positive and HER2++. I did 6 cycles of Taxotere, Carboplatin and Herceptin and a pet scan found me NED after three cycles. I finished my chemo and continued with Herceptin and Aredia (for bone mets). I also did a year of Tykerb. I am just on Herceptin now and it has been over 8 years. I am still NED and with the exception of infusions every three weeks, I live a pretty normal life. Like the other ladies said, keep track of your test results and know the drugs you are taking and the side effects. I wish you the same outstanding results that I have experienced. It is overwhelming. My kids were 8 and 11 when diagnosed and my youngest just turned 17 and my oldest will be 21. Jen

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2009 01:11PM JeninMichigan wrote: Robin I met a man online before my dx.   I was about 4 years out of a divorce and he was really the first guy I dated.   I broke it off with him because my youngest daughter was having a really hard time with me dating I got cold feet.   That was December 07.   February 08 I was diagnosed and had chemo from May - August 08.   September 08 I sent him a happy birthday text.  We talked online and I told him about my dx.   His sister was going through chemo as well and we even had the same doctor.  I met him for lunch feeling really really self conscience about my wig.   At Christmas I started wearing a baseball hat around him.   I really felt afraid because when we dated before I had really long pretty blond hair.    He was absolutely wonderful.  I got to know his sister and sat with her in the hopsital.  She died in January.   It was really really hard.    By February things were developing with more of a physical relationship.... scary!!!  He was totally not bothered by anything about me physcially.....hair, scars, port... but it was just too weird for me.    I ended up breaking it off with him again before anything "major" happened.    We still talk regularly and he said he was falling in love with me but I guess it didn't feel right for me.  Part of me thinks I liked him because I think that no one else is going to want me and then I realized he was a really nice guy and deserved more than that.   I feel bad for hurting him but I think that I probably would end up hurting him more in the end.    Dating is really hard.   I am anxious to hear what other people say.     Seems like at Christmas I feel more lonely than any other time of the year.    I have never had a problem with self confidence but I really used to be pretty girl.   Now I feel so different that is is hard to imagine someone wanting the physical person I am now   ;( Jennifer

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2014 04:23AM JeninMichigan wrote: Taxoterrible!!!   I hated that drug but darn it was super effective for me.   It took care of four decent sized liver mets and many bone mets.  In fact, after three cycles they were all gone.    But the side effects are rough.   The taste changes were awful and I had to use great imagination on what I could actually eat. I used to suck on Life Savers Butter Rum flavor ...even through the night to cut the bad garbage mouth.   I found adding clariten daily throughout treatment helped a bit with watering eyes although I had eye twitches the entire time I took that drug.    Fever, rigors and the worst stomach cramping diarrhea as if on command day 4 after treatment (i was every three weeks).    All I can say is that it is really a big gun of chemos and I sure hope they can help ease your side effects and this chemo really knocks the cancer hard.   Put some coconut oil under your eyelids.   Hang in there!!! Jennifer

Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2012 03:45PM JeninMichigan wrote: I have been on Tamoxifen and Herceptin after finishing up my chemo in August 2008.    I get the Herceptin every 21 days.   The night of infusion I get a headache and just very tired but it passes the next day.   Tamoxifen causes me many more side effects including hot flashes, weight gain, joint pain and stiffness.    I had a port for about 1 1/2 years but I had mine removed in August 2010 as it was starting to cause me discomfort.  I didn't elect to get one put back in although I might after a a while.  Right now I just get an IV in my hand.   Good luck with the two drugs.  Once you get used to them they really do not cause major problems.     I also did a year of Tykerb too which was worse than herceptin but still quite doable. Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2014 08:39PM JeninMichigan wrote: Wow ...just wow!    Even if environment plays just a part of the cause it is a part that is grossly neglected. What is common among women who are diagnosed ....cosmetics?  Exposure to chemicals?   Consider cancer clusters...there is always an underlying exposure to a chemical which is near impossible to prove and covered up.  My brother had leukemia when he was 16.  He was the third child on our block with leukemia.  In a 12 mile radius they had 5 time the entire Ohio state average for leukemia.   My mom quickly became a determined environmentalist.  The common factor among all the kids was they either attended or had attended the same school.  This school was built over an old public dump and had well water.  She finally got the EPA to test the wells but mysterious the sample was mishandled and froze rendering it useless and the wells had been capped. Case closed.  Anyway I think that some people when their immunities are low and they come in contact with such chemicals this is where is starts.  Sorry I got off topic but I think environment is totally something that should be a focus  Jen

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2010 08:56AM JeninMichigan wrote: Jenny I ran into this after I finished chemo and it was time for radiation since I had a lumpectomy.   My oncologist told me that she anticipated a fight from the local radiologists/oncologists because of my stage.  She called them and discussed my case prior to sending me over.  Here is was stage IV but NED and they denied me radiation.  In fact, one of the doctors from the group called me at work and said the Tumor Board reviewed my case and felt that the benefit did not outweigh the risk.  And since I was stage IV that they felt my cancer was going to come back and radiation was not justified.   OMG, my oncologist was so pissed.   She didn't give up.  She sent me up to the University of Michigan where they gladly gave me radiation.  Now I had to drive 67 miles out of my way every day for 6 weeks but I felt it was important.  I can see how this happens.   Luckily, my oncologist doesn't see it that way at all and that boss lady is definitely driving the bus in my treatment.    Jennifer

Posts.Content: May 5, 2018 02:09AM JeninMichigan wrote: Thanks Everyone.    Niiankrah1 - I appreciate what you are saying.  However, I am completely at peace with my decision.   I have consulted with a group of oncologists at the University of Michigan Cancer Center who have studied women exactly with my pathology (HER2 mets de novo) who have been exceptional responders to Herceptin and have been able to come off treatment without it coming back .. one now at 15 years and many nearing 10 years.    I am at peace if it comes back, I can go back on treatment (if I choose).   10 years of being in treatment takes a toll physically, financially and otherwise.   I begged to be able to raise my daughters and have done so.  While I am not ready to die by any stretch, I am also completely comfortable with the potential risk of going off treatment.    Also I am not at all off my guard.   Currently, I am in the best physical shape of my life.   I have lost 34 pounds and at 52 years old, I can outlast the 20 year olds in my workout classes.    I see my naturalist regularly and keep my life as stress free as possible.  While none of those things guarantee me anything but neither does the Herceptin as many know.   You do the very best you can do and at some point you just put it in God's hands.     Breast Cancer is like 15 different diseases all lumped under one.  We are all different and unpredictable.  What works for one we see doesn't do a thing for another.   You just can't compare each other's experiences.  My best to each one of you.  I wish I could pass out slices of this good fortune as I was share it with each of you.  Jen

Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2011 08:40AM JeninMichigan wrote: Hi Cheriee Welcome!   I do not have widespread bone mets .. just a few left hip and ribs.  I also have liver mets.  I am sure getting the results of your scans was so overwhelming for you.   I recall the day hearing my first oncologist say while shaking his head that my pet scan changed everything for me ... he said "it is everywhere".  I see you are HER2+ also.    I did 6 cycles of Taxotere, Carboplatin,  & Herceptin along wiith Zometa in 2008.  I was NED (no evidence of disease after 3 cycles) and have remained that way every since.  I am still on Herceptin, Tamoxifen and Zometa (well Aredia).   I also did a year of Tykerb in 2009 just for fun.   Are you still on Herceptin?   My opinion, I think if you responded to Herceptin it is important to keep taking it.  I know I will be on it forever and am hopeful that forever is a very long time for me.    Good for you exercising!!  It makes you stronger and helps with all the stiffness that comes with this awful treatment.   Do you take calcium and Vit. D3?   The zometa really sucks the calcium out of my body and I felt so much better after starting 1800 mg of calcium and 2500 mgs of vit D3 every day :-) Wishing you all the best. Jennifer

Posts.Content: Jul 10, 2011 09:56PM JeninMichigan wrote: LivingIt I am one of the lucky ones (at the moment anyway) who has a pretty good quality of life.   I do work full time, exercise and although I feel far from normal, I would appear to function as normal.  I feel awful as I hope I did not say something that caused you to feel bad.   I try to be cautious as I know so many ladies here struggle every day.   I have been down that road just three years ago where I could not hardly walk across my yard without being completely wiped out... bald, tired, and spent most of my time riding the couch or in the bathroom.   I sympathize totally and it especially sucks when cant take care of your kids.   It is really hard as cancer and its treatment does such different things to each of us.  It is a heavy thing to be continuously on chemo.    You are superwoman doing it alone if you did nothing else.    There are many faces to metastatic b/c.   Some of us get treatment that lets us function easier (such as Herceptin and the hormonals) and then some get stuck on the never ending chemo train.   It is a roller coaster.   I know that I am doing OK now but I know that it is a matter of time before I will likely be back on chemo.     Anyway, I am so sorry that you feel bad.    I appreciate where you are at and I would give anything to help you up.    I hope that you too get to a spot where you can start to feel normal. (((hugs)))  Jennifer

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2013 08:36AM JeninMichigan wrote: Janis Interesting study but in the end it didn't necessarily point out a huge difference.   The biggest point gleaned was that receptor status changes 49 percent of the time.  That is huge and if not offered, it should be demanded by us that recurrences and perhaps even progressions should be biopsied.   I agree the whole fat thing really is more directly related to the fact that we take drugs that make us fat and of course you will find that more than 50 percent of b/c patients are overweight.   Being overweight is a risk for some many things and we all know it.   I do appreciate the fact that studies look at breast cancer as many different diseases and each one has its own statistics.   At that start, my doctor cautioned me on looking at statistics relating to breast cancer.    When they lump it all together regardless of status and age, you get a very murky picture.   It actually is very meaningless to us individually.  Jennifer

Posts.Content: Aug 29, 2011 10:35PM JeninMichigan wrote: Thank you all for your candid replies.   I has been on my mind non stop.    I am upping her sessions with the counselor.   My children do not know I am stage IV.   My oncologist and I discussed it and she said there is no reason for me to tell them unless my treatment starts failing me.  I am glad I never did as I have been NED for over 3 years now.  Since the chemo was done in 2008, cancer has been a really small part of their lives.  I don't think the anxiety comes from their struggles with my disease.  I made really sure that my disease was mine and not theirs ... as much as I could.  Much of her issues comes from having a loser dad who has been in and out of her life.  She refers to him as a loser although she is torn up because she still wants a relationship with him.   It is a heartbreaking situation.    He absolutely is in denial about his lack of involvement in their lives.   Her pediatrician says that she thinks Olivia is fine in that regard and I have done a great job keeping her stable and secure.  The counselor says her father trying to get back in her life the last year or so has stirred up old bad issues that are coming to surface.  The pediatrician says no.. she has Generalized Anxiety disorder.. it is not related to her father but a genetic chemical imbalance.  Her father has depression and is an alcoholic.   Anyway, I am not putting her on the Zoloft ...yet.    I am calling her naturalist to see what else we can possibly do naturally.  I am also going to take her to some relaxation/yoga classes so she can learning some relaxation techniques through meditation and yoga.   I just think there has to be a better way than meds!!!!  It may get to the point but right now we will try another way.   She starts school next week which has me on edge.  I don't want her to have a panic attack at school but I also don't want her to start school feeling weirded out on meds either. Thanks so much!! Jennifer
Posts.Title: Off Topic - Zoloft for preteen Anxiety???? JeninMichigan apple

Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2012 11:36PM JeninMichigan wrote: Wow that is a tough question.   My opinion only... is that you need a combination of several things to fight this.  You need to take the chemo and the drugs; however, a healthy lifestyle will only make you healthier so that you have a better chance at not getting knocked down so hard by the drugs.    Moving and exercising to the limits you can, keeps your lymphatic system moving and fighting.   Antioxidants and supplements for your bones and joints take out inflammation that is not only painful but promotes cancer growth.    I enlisted the help of a very good naturalist who counseled me through chemo and worked well with my oncologist on supplements, vitamins, minerals.    He also gave me herbs for energy, sleep and anxiety.    He helped me with a low acid, high alkaline diet which turned my stomach and GI issues around.   The one thing I don't like is that the oncologists wants to give you a pill for everything and that pill causes other issues.  I found the naturalist was able to really help take care of my side effect issues through natural remedies that didn't cause additional side effects.    I had a very good friend who was Triple Negative with lung mets. She bought into a spiritual person's notion that he could heal her through a healthy lifestyle, certain vitamin regiment and prayers.    She didn't do the chemo and she did lose her battle.  The sad part was that she really wasn't opposed to chemo and at the point where she didn't want to do chemo or had no quality of life, she just bought into the notion that a healthy and spiritual lifestyle would save her.      Best of luck with your mom.    Jennifer

Posts.Content: Aug 31, 2012 09:49PM JeninMichigan wrote: Sarika I am so very sorry you lost your mom.   You did your very best, your mom did hers and so did the doctors.   Do not spend energy looking for blame or what ifs.  This is cancer and this is what happens over and over again despite everyone's best possible fight.     Your mom is at peace now.   You will heal in time and know that your mom is in a better place and free from her struggles here.  Here is a poem I put in my daughter's journals, called a Letter from Heaven When tomorrow starts without me , and I'm not here to see, If the sun should rise and find your eyes, filled with tears for me. I wish so much you wouldn't cry the way you did today, While thinking of the many things, we didn't get to say. I know how much you love me, as much as I love you, and each time you think of me, I know you'll miss me too. When tomorrow starts without me, don't think we're far apart for every time you think of me, I'm right there in your heart Wishing you and your family peace and healing. My deepest sympathy, Jennifer

Posts.Title: 5 Years Remission of Stage 4!!! Denny123 dreamwriter

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2010 09:40AM JeninMichigan wrote: Daisy I am hoping your biopsy comes up negative.   However, your story is very very much the same as mine.    On February 22, 2008, I had a breast biopsy that came back positive for cancer.   I had all the routine pre surgery tests, etc and everything came back clean except for a C/T that showed a little nodule on my lung.  My surgeon said she totally thought it was focal scarring and didn't order a pet.   I had the lumpectomy in March and then a few weeks later was getting ready to start my chemo at a stage 2b.   My first oncologist ordered a PET scan first to check out that lung nodule closer.  Lung nodule was indeed focal scarring but the PET scan lit up.   I had 5 lesions on my liver and mets to my ribs and hip along with a chest node.    My first oncolgoist said that changed everything and we were going for qualify of life and not a cure.   I fired him and got my second and current oncolgoist.  Her theory is this .... many stage 2 and 3 patients are likely stage 4 and are treated successfully.  Had we not had the pet scan after my surgery we would not have known about the mets.     She said if the C/T bone scans show up clean, many times they do not routinely do pets and the mets go undiagnosed.   So, I had 6 cycles of Taxotere, Carboplatin and Hercpetin along with Zometa.   After three she scanned me and I was clean ... no evidence of disease.  Every single spot resolved.   I finished my chemo, had radiation and now am on Herceptin every three weeks plus aredia (for bones) every 12 weeks.   I had a scan in late January 2010 and still am cancer free.    I will continue with Herceptin probably forever or until they find something better or as long as I remain cancer free.   My oncologist said that the good thing for me is that they knew I was stage IV and I can continue to take Herceptin.   I noticed you are Her+ and although it is aggressive, I think it is a good thing because of Herceptin and so many other drugs out there.  I am only mildy ER+ (5 percent) but I do take Tamoxifen and my onc had my ovaries yanked this year so to make sure.    I am glad she is so aggressive with me.  I am 43 years old and was 41 when diagnosed.      Feel free to PM me.  Your situation is so close to mine and I would be happy to talk to you!!! Oh and don't worry about the liver biopsy too much.  It isn't nearly as bad as it sounds.    As them to give you as much "dope" as they can to relax you.  You have to be awake and able to hold your breath but it is quick and not very painful.   I had my self so upset and really it wasn't too bad.   I think the thought of having it done and why is way worse than the actual procedure.    Throughout the first year of my treatment I took Adavan regularly for anxiety and it was truly a Godsend.   Jennifer

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2010 07:50AM JeninMichigan wrote: Carol  I did Taxotere also.  It is really a hard drug but it works.  You will feel better.   When I did this drug I had infusion on Thursday and Sunday was my all out worst day.  Slowly (very slowly) the following week I felt better.  By the following weekend I was feeling good.    However, the days immediately following the infusion are emotional too.  I am sure you are taking an oral or IV steriod.  Getting on that steriod you feel like superwoman and all anxious and hyped up but coming off it is a big crash.    I am not a super emotional person but I was a crying and irritable wreck coming off those steriods.     Not to mention you feel like $hit!!  Everyone is different but for me the energy and appetite came back.  I made myself get up and keep moving and you will do the same for your children's sake.   Don't doom yourself... you will be there for those boys.    I did 6 rounds of Taxotere/Carboplatin/Herceptin and was NED after three cycles and have remained NED (no evidence of disease = no cancer) now for 20 months now.  Your life will not always be feeling this bad.   My oncologist told me that you need to pull out the bigs guns of chemo and shock the tumor and after that it will be very manageable.    She was right.  Hang in there.  Drink as much water as you can. Lots of people disagree with this little piece of advise, but I took alot of vitamins and antioxidants during chemo... I still do today.    You can do this!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Jennifer

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2009 08:49AM JeninMichigan wrote: I am so sorry!!   For me the liver biopsy was the hardest part of this whole journey.  It was difficult to face and changed everything for me.   You need to be somewhat in a state of denial or maybe just reaching for the chance it is something else.    I guess it helps you get through the whole insanity of tests and waiting.    HOWEVER, there are treatments and it is not a death sentence.   I had alot of liver lesions plus bone mets.   After three treatments, I had a clean pet scan.    I have been off chemo since August and just had another clean pet scan.   My girlfriend is a three time b/c survivor.  Last time around she had huge liver lesions and has been now clean for four years!!   It is not a death sentence.   I am a single mom with two daughters 9 & 13.   Nothing scares me more than leaving them.... so much that you endure whatever is necessary.    Try not to focus too far ahead than what is immediately in front of you.   It is important not to get overwhelmed!!   Will keep you in my prayers!! Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2011 09:32PM JeninMichigan wrote: 38years I am sorry you are here too.    As usual, the ladies gave you some good advise and thoughts.   I agree with dismissing the MIL.  Now is the time for you to concentrate on YOU and adding stress is not helpful.    I was Stage IV pretty much from the get go too.   I had the biopsy done in February, lumpectomy in March and found out I was stage IV with liver and bone mets in April .  That was over 3 years ago and I am doing great right now.   Don't write yourself off yet.   However, I do have a journal for my daughters.  I include poems, quotes and of course I write in it often.   It helps me feel better knowning they  have something from me should things turn bad quickly. Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2018 10:27AM JeninMichigan wrote: Illimae -  I think Herceptin was primarily the driver because my mets showed up so quickly and so many and they also resolved completely so quickly.   However, I do believe that diet, exercise and supplements have played a big role in keeping me cancer free.   Since diagnosis I have also been under the care of a naturalist. For the last 7 years, I have exercised vigorously and faithfully 3-5 days a week every week. While I don't go crazy with my diet, I have not eaten fast food in over 10 years and generally eat organic and pretty clean.   I give Saturdays as a cheat day.     Boy it is hard to say for sure what keeps one person from progressing and others do.   I give 95% credit though to Herceptin.   The rest of it is building my body to be as healthy as possible to keep the beast away.  However, as we all know, it also does what it wants when it wants which is why supporting research is so important.

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2015 08:49AM JeninMichigan wrote: I am over 7 years with mets (right from the start - liver/bones) and in June it will be 7 years NED. My surgeon told me when they found my mets a grim 12 percent chance of living 5 years with my dx. My oncologist told me to ignore statistics. They are indeed outdated and faulty because they combine the entire population of breast cancer and group them. She said breast cancer itself is like 15 different diseases. You cannot compare IBC to Triple Negative to HER2 and then throw in all the different grades. Statistics lump the 85 year old woman in with the 45 year old woman. So I have followed her advise and ignore them. Jennifer
