Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2010 03:08PM JeninMichigan wrote: Hi Patti I am sure you are really scared!  First of all, remember it is not cancer until the biopsy says so.  There are lots of things that pet scan show that are light up but are not cancer.    As far the the biopsy goes, I think my liver biopsy was the scariest thing I have done so far.  The procedure itself it not difficult but the emotions, fear, consequences, etc being so life altering made it a really hard procedure.   One step at a time is all I can tell you which is so far hard not to do.  Your mind races and you are already living out your future in your mind before you even know any results.     The other thing I can tell you is that is that I had numerous lesions on my liver and ribs and hip and all of them have resolved and I am currently cancer free and have been for about 20 months.  Doesn't make it any less scary but I just wanted you to know that this disease spreading is still manageable.  Please let us know how your biopsy goes.  Will say a prayer for you!! Posts.Content: Aug 5, 2010 08:37AM JeninMichigan wrote: Jeanne I too tried to buy a wig that look like the color and general style of my hair and spent a bundle.  But when I put it on, I was like "who the hell is that in the mirror"?   I never felt like I looked like me anymore.   I also remember that awful feeling of walking into work with it on.  Amazingly, so many people did notice or never said a word except my close co-workers who knew.  In fact, lots of people at my work never knew I had cancer at all.    Believe me, you are are way more self conscious than you need to be about it.    My kids where easier.  My oldest was 13 and she didn't want to see me without my wig ever ever.    I honored that but I always wore a bandanna tied around my head and that is it.   My youngest was 9 and she was right along with me pulling globs of hair out and she always wanted to see my bald head.     As far as sadness, they will only see what you show them.     If you have hope and love in your eyes, so will they.  You are not a burden to you family.     Losing your hair (even crummy hair) is so hard.   It is not just hair but it is a very outward symbol of your disease.   It is sometimes what can make you feel normal.    I have hope for you that you won't always be bald.  Taxotere is a bad ass drug that will work for you and hopefully get you back into a more mild maintenance mode.   I did Taxotere two years ago ... hated it but it worked magic for me.     Oh, and don't even get me started on the weight gain, bad skin, nails.... WTF ... why?    Sometime you feel like, "crap just poke my eyes out while you are at it here".  I am hoping this is a down spell for you and you will get your game back on once you get over this very large hurdle.   Amazing how we can adjust and move forward ... we may hate it ... but we keep trudging along. ((((Hugs))))) Jennifer

Posts.Content: Nov 14, 2012 12:06PM JeninMichigan wrote: Difference doctors treat it differently.  They found my mets after my lumpectomy but before chemo.  My first oncologist upon finding all the mets (liver, bone & chest node) said, "on the good side, your chemo will be easier.  We are going for quality of life and not a cure."  Upon hearing that, I found another doctor.   My current oncologist said she believes many women are stage IV at diagnosis but not known because Pet scans are not the norm.  The CT/Bone scan missed my mets.  She also believes these women are treated successfully.   She told me I would get the same treatment as a stage II patient and the only difference is that I will always be in some form of treatment and be monitored more closely.  I think my HER status made a difference too.  I did Taxotere, Carbo andHerceptin.   She insisted I finish local therapy with radiation.   She took out my ovaries,  I am on Tamoxifen and I also did a year of Tykerb with Herception even though I was already NED.   And, Herceptin forever.   Sooooo, I have stayed NED now for 4 1/2 years.   So in my case, "aggressive" treatment was good.      However, if you are looking at ER/PR positive, hormonals may be the way to go.   Jennifer

Posts.Content: Sep 12, 2012 12:52PM JeninMichigan wrote: Hi Leslie  I was not able to tolerate Zometa.  The first infusion I had a fever, etc.  However, it was the subsequent infusions where I had horrible joint issues.  Every joint down to my fingers and toes hurt with Zometa.  They switched me to Aredia and I had no real issues with Aredia.  Some joint pain but hard to tell the difference between the Tamoxifen.    The infusion time sucks but I handled it great.  I was doing it every 6 weeks, then every 12, then every 16 weeks, and now I just got knocked down to once a year since my bone mets have resolved and my bone density test came back really good (payoff of exercise).    Anyway, I have been on it for about 4 years and it hasn't been an issue.  I wish you the same good fortune.   Oh, yes, have them do a long flush too before and after .. it helps. Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2016 12:42PM JeninMichigan wrote: Divine I think you asked a great question. Most of us have been offered some kind of alternative treatment that would miraculously save our lives. Hard not to wonder what would happen if you would forgo the harsh chemo drugs. While I am all in on complementary treatment, I am not in enough not to get medical drugs. However, that being said I have made some decisions to stop my AI treatment as the side effects where wreaking havoc on my quality of life. Instead I opted to be able to vigorously exercise and adopt a clean diet. However, I am only mildy ER positive and my have been NED for a long time. The one thing about most medical doctors that irritates me is that they are not well educated on diet, supplements and complementary options. My first oncologist dismissed supplements all together and told me take nothing ... not even a multivitamin - while on chemo/radiation. I went to the University of Michigan and they were completely fine with my very long list of supplements and further offered me a consult with a nutritionist. Too many medical doctors are quick so just say no and not even consider the benefit of supplements. How great it would be if our medical doctors were willing to work with naturalists to give us every benefit possible. Jennifer

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2013 06:46PM JeninMichigan wrote: Hi Tortoise I am so sorry you are amongst us.  First, I want to say I hate when doctors give a time line.   No one knows and really the statistics take into accounts all kinds of breast cancer, ages, etc.   You cannot use those statistics to determine your time left.     More than that, I hate mothers with young children being diagnosed.  There is no fear like that of leaving your children behind.    Your husband is being a selfish ass right now.   However, there is no reason to plan for your death.  I know you need to feel like everything will work out OK when you are no longer here but you need to focus on living right now.     When I was dianosed with liver and bone mets my girls were 12 and 8.  I was divorced and there father was a real piece of sh#t who took very little interest in their life in any sort of way.    They are now 17 and 13 and my oldest is graduating from high school this spring.  For the last 4 1/2 years I have been living a very good quality of life.  Focus on the positive.     You can't iron out everything right now for your kids.   There will be time ahead of you for it!! Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2009 11:56PM JeninMichigan wrote: I am on the Herceptin for Life program.   I was stage IV from the start with liver/bone mets. AFter three cycles of TCH .. I was NED and have stayed NED for about 14 months now.   My onc is treating me like stage two because my cat and bone scan didn't show any mets before the lumpectomy.   I had a PET only because of a tiny lung nodule that was really just  focal scar...but boom ... three weeks after my CAT scan... all these mets showed up.  The problem with HER2+ is that it is aggressive and fast.    Having just one tiny bone met is great but it still means that the cancer traveling beyond the local area.   If it were me and I was stage III and HER2+ and they offered me herceptin for life... I would take it!!   My onc told me too many times she has burned by the insurance company making her stop herceptin and two months later the cancer is back.    If you tolerate it well and your mugas are good, I would continue with it.  Jennifer

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2016 09:08AM JeninMichigan wrote: Lisajo6 We each develop our own coping .. right or wrong you eventually figure out a way that helps you. I am coming up on 8 years with mets (liver and bone) and the initial shock is devastating. Once I had my treatment plan in place, it made me feel better to get some of my ducks in order. I had a wlll made and took care of all that stuff that maybe should have been done regardless. After that, I chose to put dying aside and concentrate on living. I made some deliberate changes in my life - not in grasping at survivorship but just to try to live a healthier life and to stay as strong as possible (diet, exercise, reducing stress). It may take antidepressants, counseling, etc but getting out from under the dark cloud really helps. There are things that take you back to a little place of darkness ... wondering if that pain or cough is progression... but trying to keep is mostly in check is what gets you though. Since I have been diagnosed I have gone on wonderful vacations, moved, leased my third car, gotten a promotion, seen my daughter graduate and hoping to see the next one do so next year. It doesn't have to be a death sentence. Having a doctor who will answer your questions and learning about your disease and treatment option helped me feel like there is some control to what could happen. Lots of us living long and productive lives. Be one of us and know that it is possible! Jen

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2016 05:30AM JeninMichigan wrote: Hi Rose I am so sorry to read about the misery you are going through. Don't even feel like you are whining!! The side effects of the drugs we take often do us more harm than the cancer itself. You may well be having side effects specific to you from the drug combination that are not on the "common side effects" list associated with the drugs. Arimidex gave me high blood pressure and extreme insomnia to the point I was barely functioning. Aromisin wasn't any better for me. I did much better on Tamoxifen. Right now I chose to take no anti hormonals but I am less than 5 percent ER positive and have been NED for a long time. My doctor prefers I take something but I made the choice this time. It well could be your body's reaction to the combination. I would seriously give it consideration to take a lower dose or look at Tamoxifen. I hope you get relief and a plan soon. My heart goes out to you having such struggles. Much Luv Jen

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2012 08:11AM JeninMichigan wrote: Formygirls Did you say your liver path did come back as HER2+?    If so, this could be an incredibly good thing for you.  I'll tell you the story of one of my very dear friends.  She had gone through two ER+ diagnosis - one in each breast.   After her second diagnosis she got pregnant while on the hormonals.  They had to stop all treatment.  When her baby was six weeks ago, she had severe abdominal pain.  They did a scan and she had a huge tumor taking over her liver.  The doctor gave her a very grim prognosis.   They biopsied the tumor and it was no longer ER+ but HER2+.  The oncologist was ecstatic and she didn't understand.  He told her options were wide open.  She did an aggressive treatment of Taxotere and Herceptin.   It took her to NED where she stayed for five years and was held that way on Herceptin only.    Just wanted to share with you.  If your receptors changed to HER2 make sure you are getting Herceptin added to your chemo .. pronto!!! Wishing you the best and keeping you close in thought. Jennifer

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2016 10:02PM JeninMichigan wrote: Hi DezyMarie I am hoping you do hear those magical words. I was diagnosed in February 2008 with mets from the start. I had four tumors on my liver, right ribs and left hip. Her2 positive and slightly ER positive (<5%). I did six cycles of Taxotere, Carboplatin and Herceptin. After three cycles, my oncologist did a pet scan and all of my tumors were resolved with no evidence of metastatic disease. I completed my chemo and then I did one year of Tykerb with the Herceptin for brain protection and have continued with Herceptin every three weeks ever since. I also took about 3 1/2 years Tamoxifen and about a year of Arimidex but I stopped the hormonals as I had bad side effects. And during all this time I was taking Aredia but am off that now too. I am still NED and just doing Herceptin every three weeks. My quality of life is very good. I hope this provides you with a little hope too! Jennifer

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2012 03:59AM JeninMichigan wrote: I have been researching soy (particulary isoflavones) consumption and breast cancer for four years now.  I have during these four years actively taken a pure form of genestein soy isoflavones even against my doctor's recommendations.   Naturally and non GMO soy has been proven to show benefit in breast cancer.   Of course, you can equally produce many studies showing the opposite.  It is the type of soy consumed (non GMO vs. GMO) and the use of non pure soy additives that differ the results in the studies.  Four years ago I felt very secure in what I was doing and I felt like sooner or later this controversial issue will be proven and published.   For now, most all doctors still will tell you to stay away from soy.   To be safe, I think most b/c patients will err on the side of caution and steer clear.   I am not usually very public about my decision because it was one based on my own time well spent in seminars and working with a holistic center but not very well received by the mainstream.   My b/c is <5% ER+.  Jennifer

Posts.Content: May 13, 2011 12:57PM JeninMichigan wrote: Alicia I saw a naturalist doctor the week after I started chemo.   My GI track was instantly a mess. .  He gave me so much good advise and instruction on eating a high alkaline - low acid diet.  Kind of like balancing the PH in your pool water .. he said my stomach was like green pool water.  It really helped me get back in order.   Probiotics have been another miracle for my guts.   Additionally he provided me advise on various other supplements.  I have a big list of them I take daily.   Does it work???  I couldn't say for sure... however I will tell you that I worked nearly every day during chemo, I didn't catch as much as a sniffle and I was NED in 3 cycles and have stayed that way.  Now, I give credit for the NED to Taxotere and Herceptin but I give my health otherwise credit to the help from the naturalist and supplements.   Vit D and Calcium at the minimum is a must.   I took a boat load of antioxidants too.    I am not big on the fad stuff like eating asparagus three times a day.   However, basic stuff my naturalist told me like, no processed stuff (of course), eat a slice of pineapple with before every meal (balances Ph)  eat a handful of spinach and red grapes every day.   No Beer ... drink red wine (yes!!!!).   I could go on and on as I have been seeing him for over three years.   You are welcome to PM me if you want to know more. Jennifer

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2011 04:18PM JeninMichigan wrote: Sometimes it just gets so tempting when you have a customer/client that goes off about something that in the grand scheme of things is so meaningless.    I am guilty of letting it slip myself.   I had a customer who was calling me and calling me while I was in the infusion center getting my herceptin/Aredia.  I had my laptop so I emailed him and said that I was not able to use the phone but I would call him in two hours as soon as I was free.  He replied and demanded that I must excuse myself from whatever meeting I was in and take his call as it was a matter of urgency.  Finally I told him I was in the middle of getting chemo.   All of the sudden, he was all apologies and said absolutely please just call me when you are free.   When I called him he wanted to know what kind of cancer and alot of questions.   His mother died of breast cancer.  I felt a little foolish really after I said it but he just wouldn't back off.    I say whenever possible,... ignore the rants of your clients and let it bounce right off you. Jennifer

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2010 08:45PM JeninMichigan wrote: Michele It is good you are getting a biopsy for a couple of reasons.  First, just to make sure it is indeed cancer.  If it is, then it is most likely breast cancer.  The second good reason to get a scan is to make sure the pathology of the cancer is the same.  Sometimes women with liver mets find that it is has turned HER2+.   If it is Her2+, then your course of drugs would change.    I had four liver lesions right from the start.  Chemo and Herceptin zapped those and they have been gone for the last two plus years.     Best of luck to you.   The liver biopsy isn't horrible.  Just ask to be as sedated as possible mostly so you can relax.   ((hugs)) Jennifer

Posts.Content: Aug 16, 2010 11:53AM JeninMichigan wrote: Jenn I am chiming in late but happy to see you are feeling a bit better.    It is hard to remember that not every pain you feel is cancer.   We all still get other illnesses and the chemo is going to give you alot of side effects.   I had liver mets and bone mets.   To this day, I get pain in my right ribs ... of course, I still think is it my liver or my ribs???    However, I have been NED now for over 2 years.  I think less about that pain and realize that my body has been really put through the wringer.    You can never discount how hard it is to lose your hair.   Surely is a reason to feel horrible.  Like Fitz said, it is a visible sign that you have cancer and a harsh reminder every time you look in the mirror.    For me, distraction and drugs during treatment kept me sane.   I kept busy as heck when I was awake... read lots and lots of books.   At nighttime, I took Ativan to stop my crazy mind from going to the dark side so I could sleep.    Because I have kids I had to keep a happy, upbeat face on.  I am a single mom and my kids where very afraid of losing me. .. so I kept the "everything is going to be ok" face on most of the time.    I am not sure about you but my oncologist would turn me around whenever I got into a dark spot.   She gave me confidence and courage.  She told me success stories and options.    You need to have that reassurance.   Oh yeah, she also prescribed me anti anxiety - anti depressesants on the spot.   Wishing you peace and success with your treatment! Jennifer

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2016 12:09PM JeninMichigan wrote: It is true that there is no money in researching herbs and supplements ... so why do it. The conventional medical field will not accept the clinical studies that are conducted outside of the medical arena. Stephanie, I agree that you need to do your own research. I have gone to many conferences and my naturalist doctor has spent hours talking with me about the pros and cons and research behind natural remedies. I haven't dismissed conventional therapy as I still get Herceptin infusions every three weeks. (although my ND has suggested it is not necessary). My medical doctor has also suggested some of the supplements are not necessary but in the end it is my decision. 7 1/2 years NED after multiple liver mets and quite a few bone mets, I feel like I have made good educated choices. The combination of the pharma drugs, herbs, supplements, moderate diet changes and significant exercise changes have all contributed to my good health rather than just luck. I would never blindly follow any medical doctor or naturalist without researching everything I take. It is well worth the time to consider all of your options. Jen

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2016 12:13PM JeninMichigan wrote: Griselda13 It is true that the experience with this disease is so very different from patient to patient. When I was in my first chemo, my naturalist used to tell me to try to get physical activity as much as I possibly could. He said that believe it or not that moving around would actually give me more energy and do me more good than laying/sleeping. So even if I could only walk 50 feet at a time, to do that as much as I could. It was frustrating because tasks that would be easy for someone else to do, I would have to cut into blocks. Even folding laundry or putting away dishes. Also, if there are any better days during the treatment cycle, save outings for those days. Sometimes it helps to have that to look forward to. I hope that there are some decent days for her. By all means, communicate all of this to her doctor. They may be able to help tweak drugs that can help provide quality of life. Don't be shy in telling her doctor what is going on. This disease and treatment affects us all differently. Take advantage of any kind of help available include antidepressants, etc. Lots of good suggestions on making her environment comfortable and mixing it up. Interesting movies, documentaries, books, puzzles. Women are always the caretakers and it is frustrating for most of us to have to be tended to which makes it worse. My wise oncologist told me that this time is about me and this time is about your wife and concentrating on her. She is very lucky to have you to be there. I sure do hope that better days are ahead of her. Jennifer

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2011 07:38PM JeninMichigan wrote: Joy It is true that everyone's experience with B/C is different.  Breast cancer is not one disease but made of many different diseases.   Your friends ER/PR, HER2 status makes it its own unique disease.   My oncologist told me to forget the statistics and survival rates.  They are often outdated and take an accumulation of all the types and ages of B/C patients and throws them into one pot.    I believe I am going to live for many years.   I just had my three year anniversary with mets right from the start to liver and  bones.   I have been NED for over 2 1/2 years and my quality of life is very good.    Chemo sucked but it was only 4 months for me and then slowly I started to get my life back.   I am in treatment still and will be forever but it isn't bad at all.   Your friend needs some time to digest what she has been told and her options.    I was stage IV but I still had a lumpectomy and followed up with radiation.   I wasn't written off as.....terminal so why bother with the primary tumor location. I hope you are able to help your friend come to a decision to pursue some kind of treatment.    Jennifer

Posts.Content: Nov 25, 2013 07:56AM JeninMichigan wrote: Raro No great suggestions just my sincere sympathy. I had RLS after I had my first baby and it was just torture. Like snakes crawling up your legs. I used to have my former husband wrap my legs tight in wraps and I would squeeze them as hard as I could. It is a feeling that just can make you absolutely crazy trying to go to sleep. I don't have RLS anymore. It actually went away about a year after my second child was born but I lived for 5 years with it. My doctor told me it was vascular changes probably from the pregnacy. I tried magnesium and it helped. By the way, some chemos tank your magnesium (like Carobplatin) so it might be worth looking into. Jennfier

Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2015 09:39AM JeninMichigan wrote: When I had mine out, the surgery was pretty easy. When they tell you to take it easy though for 24-48 hours after surgery, it is good advise. I didn't listen. Because I felt pretty good, I was up and moving quite a bit and this created that awful gas that goes up into your chest and shoulders. I had a fair amount of pain really only due to the gas. As far a menopause symptoms, I had already been put into chemo pause for 1 1/2 years prior to the OOPH so the hot flashes and mood shifts didn't dramatically increase more than what I had already been experiencing. There are options to help you with the mood shifts and hot flashes so you don't need to just suck them up. I have gone the supplement route and take a day and night supplement that keeps me pretty even on the moods and hot flashes. When I run out, I do gradually notice the increase. Best of luck. Jen

Posts.Content: Jun 24, 2011 10:09AM JeninMichigan wrote: Thanks Ladies.  You have given me so much good advise to ponder.    There are a couple of things about me that I know I have created my own worst enemy.   One is after my divorce, I felt so guilty because I didn't want my kids to come from a broken marriage but their dad living here was doing way more harm than good.   But I wanted things to be as normal as possible so we stayed on the farm.   Now they have recovered from the divorce but the property value is such that I am upside down and so here I will stay until it turns around.    I haven't really dated at since I have been divorced.    I also don't do much outside of the house except work (and I work alot).  My daughters stay tight to me and I realize this is probably not so good.   right now I am making a vow to do some things for me.   I am really picky about my house being clean and garden weeded, etc.   Yesterday I did not vacuum... no big deal right?    For me, huge deal.. I mean huge.  I am really a weirdo about it so I am trying to let go a little.   Last night I went to a  "Fight Club" actually it is an amazing work out session combining martial arts, kick boxing, and some ass kicking exercises.   The ladies there were AMAZING and so welcoming to me.   I am going to go at 5:00 AM Mon-Wed-Fri before work and on Saturdays.   It is a little ambitious but it felt great.   Although today I can hardly walk.   Tonight I am going to a Disco Party with my girlfriends.   My kids are OK with it and I think it is important for them to see me live a little of my own life and be happy.   I need the break away too.   I hope a few subtle changes might help.   I am willing to try to some meds too.  I am not really willing to put my daughter on meds though.    Not yet.  She is a difficult child and always has been.  That is part of it.  This panic though is rough to watch her go through.  I just started taking her to counseling and I hope it helps her work through it.     This damn disease really takes a toll on everyone.    I need to get back on my game again and take some control over it though.   I thank God I am right now not taking chemo... i really do because then it would really all collapse.   My heart goes out to the ladies that are in chemo and especially trying to balance the kids needs.   It is so hard.  Thanks again. Jennifer

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2018 11:59AM JeninMichigan wrote: Hello.   I was dx with mets from the start - Liver & bone in 2008.   Luckily, Herceptin worked very well for me and I was NED after three chemo treatments including Herceptin.  I took Herceptin ever since for over 9 years and remained NED.   Coming up on one year ago, I stopped taking Herceptin completed and currently am not on any treatment.    I continued working the entire treatment time but being a single mom I didn't have much choice.   Today, I am in the best physical shape of my life and very happy.  Not everyone has this success with Herceptin, but there are several HER2 targeted therapies and hopefully one of them will be equally successful for you.  My cancer was very aggressive.   In four weeks I went to no visible mets on c/t to four sizable tumors on my liver, most of my right ribs, left hip and several chest nodes picked up on a pet scan before I started chemo.     Best to you.  Jen

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2014 07:36AM JeninMichigan wrote: I would love to know the answer to this question.   I have been NED now for 5 1/2 years.   I was Stage IV from the start with multiple liver mets, bones and chest nodes.   I am a Grade 9 and on the Nottingham's scale I was a 9. My cancer had burst through one of the lymph nodes and into the surrounding tissue.  I went from undectable cancer on a c/t - bone scan to getting a base line PET 4 weeks later and then it light up .    So it would appear my cancer was running wild and free quickly.   It is surprising that it resolved after 3 cycles of chemo and has stayed inactive.    I still get Herceptin every three weeks and have no intention of stopping.  However, I have noticed in the last 18 months  that I feel more and more side effect from the Herceptin about 4 hours after infusion that are sticking with me into the next morning.   I used to get it and go without even feeling like I had anything.     The only benefit as I understand is that when you are Stage IV from the start and become NED from your first line of treatment, that the cancer has not become immune yet to chemo and you have more treatment options.  I do like the reset idea though! Jennifer
Posts.Title: Are all NEDs created equal?? Iwillwinthisbattle Bestbird

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2014 09:07AM JeninMichigan wrote: Hi Reader I have been NED now for 6 years and I hesitate to use the term remission.   I think remission is an older term..  My brother had leukemia (ALL) when we he was 16 and he went into remission.  However, the doctors told us that he would have to remain in remission for 12 years before they would say he was cured.  (Which he did and now 33 years later still is) .   Many of the other patients would be "thrown out of remission".  The lingo has changed.    Below is the medical definition of remission as it pertains to cancer:  So I based on this, I guess you could use remission and NED interchangeably.     Doesn't really change the outcome.   As I always say, the cat is out of the bag and it is a matter of time before it shows up again.   I feel extremely blessed to have had six years without active cancer but still in active treatment anyway.   I agree though that given the grim stats, I wouldn't want to give any newcomers an unrealistic hope.   I know I am an oddity as far as normal goes with this disease. Jen remission(reh-MIH-shun)

Posts.Content: Jul 1, 2010 03:39PM JeninMichigan wrote: Question for you... Have you taken Herceptin?   If so, I assume it stopped working?     My oncologist told me that her fear is that once Tykerb is proving itself to be as effective as Herceptin (which it is getting to that point), that doctors and insurance companies will not allow Herceptin only Tykerb.  Since Tykerb is so much harder to tolerate, that will be totally to the patients disadvantage.    Since you are HER2+, there are other options for you than Tykerb. I took it for a year along with Herceptin.   Other than the trots and some major skin issues, I didn't have the problems you are talking about.    How about a second opinion on your situation with another oncolgoist.    You obviously CANNOT live this way.   Even with Stage IV, you can have a very good quality of life.  I am on just Herceptin right now and NED, my life is relatively normal as far as physical limitations. Posts.Content: May 9, 2013 01:22AM JeninMichigan wrote: Cancer takes so much away from us.  It is really hard to accept all those things you will never be able to do.   Many of us had to give up our breasts, reproductive organs, hair, jobs, spouses, hobbies, careers and ability to carry out every day functions.    It really sucks.   In exchange, we just want to extend our life.   Being a single mom, my greatest  fear is leaving my kids without a mom (their dad is pos).   I have gone to extremes to do whatever it takes to live to see my youngest graduate high school.  She was 8 when it started and she just turned 14.   Although potential unlikely for me to go 10 years stage IV, it is my reason for getting up in the morning.    You are so young but still at that age where you are hearing the clock ticking, it put pressure on you to make a decision.   Honestly, having a child makes treatment that much harder.   The stress of worry about a baby and the physical drain is going to be so hard on you.   I don't know how some of our moms with very young babies do it.   As someone said, a rock solid support system is critical.   I wouldn't trade my daughters for anything but man when they were younger, some days it was all I could do to get them to just go to bed so I could lay down.   If you are doing this alone, give it careful thought.  I think healthy single moms are put through the wringer.   Add continuous cancer treatments and you are walking constantly uphill.   The worst part though is when I look at my daughters and it breaks my heart to pieces knowing their secure world could be shattered when the beast rears its ugly head again and that is a fear I can't put strongly enough into words.   On the flip side, having her2 cancer more options for treatments are becoming available.  Most of them are not terribly toxic.   I have been on just Herceptin for over 4 years and it is manageable.  You may carry out your dream of having a baby (even through a surrogate) and live for many, many years.  With the right support system, it is certainly doable. I hope you can find peace in your decision.   My heart goes out to you.  Jennifer Jennifer
Posts.Title: Children after chemo? Z28Femme Latte

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2013 07:46PM - edited Jan 30, 2013 02:52AM by JeninMichigan Oh my gosh ... WHY YES .. it is all those things and more!!   Being too fat, eating sugar, prervatives, processed food, exposure to chemicals, pesticies, herbacides, lead, asbestos.  It is having babies too late in life or not at all, breast feeding or no breast feeding, birth control pills, alcohol, smoking, stress, your shampoo, conditioner and parabins in your makeup.    it is from wearing an underwire bar, using deodorant.    Living on a farm, living in the city, being Jewish, family history, no family history...... it just goes on and on and on!!  Stop beating yourself up.   The healthiest and more careful women I know have breast cancer and other forms of cancer.  Like you, I know women who are just reckless with their health and they are healthy as can be.    Let's face it ... they don't know what is causing it.   While many things can be associated with it, you can't take the blame for your breast cancer.   Personally, I feel like I have been a very healthy person up until I was diagnosed.  Social drinker, not a smoker.  A healthy weight with lots of decent food and exercise.   No family history.   I will say though prior to my diagnosis I went through  a hellish divorce and was left on a farm with two young daughters.    I seriously believe stress weakened me but who knows for sure. Please don't beat yourself up.   None of us knows why.   Jennifer

Posts.Title: 8 Rounds of Taxotere, Perjeta, Herceptin? Or not? rosetide rosetide

Posts.Content: Aug 31, 2016 06:15PM JeninMichigan wrote: Rosetide Although I can't tell you if this is totally true, but I have heard several times that older patients can actually do better with the strong chemos and it is the younger ones that have more trouble with it. While you are young and you do want to be able to hit it hard.. you also want to be able to live a long life and not have the chemo disable or kill you either. It is a delicate dance between controlling the cancer and having quality of life. You have certainly been through some difficult treatment plans. The HER2 targeted drugs are very good at maintaining if you respond well and they can do this alone. Good luck to you. We don't all call it Taxoterrible for nothing. Jennifer
Posts.Title: 8 Rounds of Taxotere, Perjeta, Herceptin? Or not? rosetide rosetide

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2010 09:45AM JeninMichigan wrote: Flachica You are very young and have stage IV cancer. ... that is a huge blow in itself.  However, having these bad scans and not getting a long lasting response is so much to swallow.   Honey, I don't know what to say to help you deal with this terrible hand.   I can tell you I too was diagnosed Stage IV from the start with liver and bone mets.  Although not as young as you, but I was 42 years old - single mom with two daughters and a whole lot of responsibility on my shoulders.   I was lucky to have a response from Herceptin but I also did take a year of Tykerb with Herceptin following my TCH chemo.    Tykerb is a great drug and I have been told it work great in tandem with Herceptin.   You have to hold on to the hope that it may be your ticket to get back to getting a good response.    Also try to remember they are doing so many studies with therapies targeting HER2+.  They know that there are certain individuals who develop an immunity to Herceptin and they are getting working on the therapy for those people like you.    Is it Tykerb ... maybe or maybe not?   Maybe though Tykerb will hold you until the new drug is tested and proved.    Tykerb isn't as easy as Herceptin but it is way better than Taxotere or Carbo.     Take care of your body and take care of your mind too.  If you need some help from an antidepressant or anti anxiety, then please seek this out.   I have lots of hope for you.  I can't take away the anxiety of worrying if you will respond and for how long.   In time, it is something you have to push out of your mind and keep living for today.      It is a way of thinking that we all learn to develop that keeps the dark cloud of cancer from ruining our days. Not sure if all this rambling helped at all... but at the very least I understand how you may feel doomed but I have great hope for you living many many years.   On another note, you may always feel free to vent here with us.    Jennifer

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2011 08:27AM JeninMichigan wrote: Jenn Don't give up yet.   I too had a rapid spread.  I went in less than 4 week from nothing showing up on a c/t scan to a pet showing 4 lesions on my liver (largest being just under 4 cms) and mets to my ribs and left hip.    All of these resolved after three cycles of chemo.   So as fast as they came, we were knock them back down.   I hope the same is for you.    Not sure what your insurance coverage is like but there is help out there.  I have a rather high deductible and co-insurance.  My cancer center was able to get my co-pay assistance which took care of $3500.00 of my annual obligation.  Something like this could help ease your financial burden and make your decision to take some time away a little easier.  Let me know if you need the specifics.  I have the paperwork at home. Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2013 09:47AM JeninMichigan wrote: Luann My kids are younger so I have only had these discussions with my sister.  I actually meant with a local funeral home here and they did for free a final wishes packet.   You actually outline what funeral home, what kind of service, music to be played, visitation hours, creatmation, etc.   I put this with my will and other important papers in my safe and let my sister know where it was.  However, hopefully I last another five years and when my kids are a little older, I will certainly have this out in the open.  I have a very dear friend whose dad had stage IV melanoma and he tried so hard to get his dad to talk about these kind of issues and he clammed up.  When he passed, they couldn't find a will and they know he had one because he was an attorney.  It has been a full year and everything in his estate is a mess.    Sometimes I think it helps us just go on knowing these details are shored up.  I would approach it likes this ... it is a good idea for everyone to know wishes of their parents no matter what age.   My parents many years ago purchased their plots and paid for them.    My mom has some nice jewelry and has already assigned which kid gets what.  We jokingly refer to our rings when we see her where them.  It isn't morbid .. it is part of life and wish Stage IV cancer looming over our heads, it is more even more of a practical thing to do.    Good luck to you.   Hope you are feeling better too!! Jennifer PS.  I am originally from Ohio but have lived in Michigan for the past 13 years. There is NO way in hell I want to be buried here.

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2011 01:54AM JeninMichigan wrote: Try some "bag balm" and wrap up your fingers at night with saran wrap or cotton gloves.  I used to call it my spa treatment.  I like it better than Vaseline (besides remember Vaseline is really petroleum ) I swear those cracked finger tips are the worst.  I also used liquid bandaid on mine too.    I took a product called Transfer Factor when I was on Tykerb and it got my diarrhea in check quickly.    Also, try some probiotics too.   I am not a big fan of Imodium.  My naturalist said to avoid it at all costs.  I used it at first but once I found the magic balance between the transfer factor and probiotics, I was all better.     My oncologist gave me some Tykerb breaks every so often.  I would get a two week vacation.   I am sure one day isn't going to hurt you.    Jennifer

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2016 01:19PM JeninMichigan wrote: My mets where discovered right after my lumpectomy. However, my oncologist still insisted on me finishing my local therapy with breast radiation. This was in 2008 and the school of thought was more of the "why bother" approach due to my stage. In fact so much that I was denied locally and had to drive 60 miles every day to the University of Michigan to get radiation. My onc's theory was to give me every possible percentage of a chance at longevity. She has treated me all the way along as if I have an earlier stage cancer. I have been NED now for 7 1/2 years so I side with her thoughts. Seems like a personal choice too. I myself would rather reduce the tumor load by surgery. Not sure if it would minimize the amount or intensity of chemo you need to kill off the tumor. It is certainly worth serious thought. Jen

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2009 10:48PM JeninMichigan wrote: I just reread the original post and wanted to add that talking about our sickness does not give energy to it.   It gives energy to us to be able to talk about things with people who understand and can relate..   It is good therapy to be able to lend support and encouragement to our sisters who are down and to receive this support from someone who really does know how you feel.      I am not interested in knowing what caused my cancer so I can blame anyone or anything I did..BUT if it keeps it at bay I am all for knowing.  That is my own personal feelings on stress.    If keeping my stress level to a low roar might keep me strong and cancer free, I am all about it.  It is a good topic for those that want to participate.   However, if you don't want to get caught up in reading the not so pretty side of b/c you should stay away from the Stage IV secton.  Reality is Stage IV b/c is not so pretty and happy and this is the one place for sure where we can let loose and not feel guilty because we made someone feel uncomfortable about our situation.  Jennifer

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2011 01:24PM JeninMichigan wrote: I can say enough good about Probiotics.   I finished up Tykerb in December 2009 and the year 2010 was a nightmare for me with GI issues.  By June I was convinced and my doc suspected too that maybe something bad was happening in my colon.   It was my naturalist that told me to get on some probiotics quick.   Within four days, I was normal and felt normal for the first time in forever.    I don't think they are going to stop the diarrhea but your GI system will just feel so much better.   He told me ... you are constipated.   I told him no I am not, I am going 15 times a day.   He said .. yes you are constipated.   Well he was right because I was never totally relieved.    I take Zygest-pro by Physiologics.   At first I took one with every meal and now I just take one with dinner.   He said I could take Doctor Ohirra Acidophilous Pearl too - just one at bedtime as it is less expensive.  However, I have been so happy with the Zygest I am afraid to switch. Shop for pricing on the Transfer Factor   It is not cheap.   If you are not allergic to mushrooms, I would do the Transfer Factor Plus (by 4 Life).    I actually take a double dose - 4 a day (2 in the morning and 2 at night).  I have since the start of chemo.    It is freaking expensive but was a small price to pay for not pooping your pants.    :-) Jennifer

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2009 09:59PM JeninMichigan wrote: Zeeka It is ironic you posted this message.  This morning I was wondering what common demoninators we might all have had  I was going to post regarding stress.   Part of me thinks that hormonal issues are to blame and then for some cancers part of me really thinks stress weakened our bodies to let the cancer invade.  I am very mildly ER positive.   However, prior to my diagnosis I went through a really ugly divorce.   My husband had clinicl depression which he would not get treated and was an alcoholic.    He maxed out all our credit cards and left me and my two daughters with a 10 acre farm.   My youngest was 4 at the time and it was really really hard on her.   At the same time our company was sold and new owners took over.   Also when they tested my Vitamin D it was deficient.  So, I really attribute alot to stress.  also the year prior to my diagnosis I had really bad gum issues .. .gingivitis.   I have always heard that your gums show disease that is else where in your body. My paternal grandmother died of ovarian cancer at a young age but that is the only other cancer in the family except my brother had leukemia.  Who else harbored alot of stress before diagnosis? Jennifer

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2009 08:46PM JeninMichigan wrote: KLee I did Taxotere last summer with Carboplatin and Herceptin.    It was a hard drug but I really only had a few bad days.   I had it every three weeks and would get it on Thursday and Sunday was my only really on the couch day.    Yes, that taste is horrible.  Everything tastes like metal for a few days and then some things for the whole duration burn ... for me tomato sauce, ketchup.   The gastrointestinal issues where probably my biggest complaint.     However, I took to a high alkaline - low acid diet and it was the best thing I could have done for my belly.   This means balancing your PH. . So, after 3:00 PM ... no meats, ice cream, beer, lots of veggies .. especially brocholi, califlower, melons, almonds, leafy greens.   YOu would think with all that fruit and veggies my lower GI would have been worse but it really made me feel much better.   Other best advise is drink drink drink ... water if you can.   I would add a freezy pop (ice pop) to my water to help counter the metal taste.  The more water the better.  You get that drug flushed through your system.    I am a single mom with two daughter, a small farm (about 35 animals) and a full time job.  other than a little help with push mowing, I didn't miss a beat on this drug.   Yes, I felt like poo poo but it was doable.    I hope it is for you too.   One thing is ... it kicked my cancers butt to the curb!!   Congrats on 10 years at Stage IV ... Jennifer

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2009 11:05AM JeninMichigan wrote: Nanalinda.    What a beautiful story.   You should feel proud and carry that with you always.   Certainly that made a huge difference. Sometimes we can make a difference in someone's life and it isn't obvious to us.   I have always thought I have made more of a difference in animals' lives than people (aside from my family).   I have a soft spot for cats and dogs and have rescued countless.  In fact, laying at my feet are my two doggy rescues.    However, a girl at our office sent me a card last Christmas.  She is a recovering alcoholic and single mom.   She struggles like many to make ends meet and she struggles to stay sober.    She said she was feeling suicidal and extremely overwhelmed and unable to make it work last fall.   However, she told me she got inspiration every day from me to keep going.  She said watching me go through radiation every day for six weeks and driving 67 miles out of my way to do it and on top of raising two children alone and continued coming to work every day made her keep realize if I could do it so could she.   I had no idea that I had any effect on anyone around me like that and was stunned when she told me I essentially saved her life.    So to those of you who think you never have made a difference... I am certain that you have!!  Sometimes random acts of kindness to strangers can really make a difference.    I had an old guy tell me one day as I was rushing out of a grocery store .. he said "honey, slow down.  don't rush through life.  take time to enjoy your youth because it goes by fast".   I think about that old dude often!! Jennifer

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2016 03:59PM JeninMichigan wrote: Hi DLS23 Our cancer path is a little different but I will throw my experienced out there for you to consider. When I was dx back in 2008 it was first through to be stage 2b. I had a lumpectomy and was getting ready for chemo and they wanted to do a pet scan to check a tiny lung nodule that appeared on my ct scan prior to surgery. The lung nodule turned out to be nothing but focal scarring but the pet scan showed multiple lesions on my liver, right ribs, hip and chest nodes. Now I am HER2+ so I really had to have chemo to go along with the Herceptin so having chemo was not a choice. However, my first oncologist said he was opting for an easier chemo protocol since we were not going for a cure anymore and just quality of life. I thankfully got a second opinion and her thoughts were that she thinks many patients who do not get pet scans are really stage IV at diagnosis and are treated successfully. She wanted to give me every opportunity to still try for a cure and ordered the same chemo that she would a stage 2b patient in addition to completing local therapy (radiation) after my lumpectomy. I did 6 cycles of chemo, several years of hormonal treatment, and have stayed on Herceptin since and am still NED now 7 1/2 years later. Again, I'll preface it by saying I had to have chemo because of the Herceptin but would you want to be treated the same as an earlier stage patient? It might be false hope or is the theory correct that many patients are not diagnosed with mets because they may not get a pet scan. Good luck with your decision.. it is not easy to say yes to chemo given the option not to do it. Jennifer

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2014 10:58AM JeninMichigan wrote: Iwillwin ... my oncologist told me she believes many early stage b/c patients are actually stage IV and not caught as a PET scan is not usually done as a base line without cause.   I was a technically stage 2b and before chemo started they wanted to check a tiny lung nodule that showed up on my ct scan prior to my lumpectomy.   My surgeon argued it was likely focal scarring but my first oncologist wanted to review it further.  Turns out it was indeed focal scarring; however, my pet scan showed four lesions on my liver the largest measuring 4 cm, most of my right upper ribs and my left hip and also chest nodes.   My old oncologists was stunned that it showed all those mets when the ct scanned showed a tiny focal node.   He bascially wrote me off after reivew of my pet scan and said he would treat me for quality and extension of life.   I left and never went back.   My second oncologist was all over my treatment and said she would treat me as if it were stage 2b because she feels many women are likely stage IV like me and not diagnosed with a pet.   Because of the cost, it is not usually routine.   My benefit in catching the mets are that I am constantly in treatment and under watch even though I am NED i still can get Herceptin every three weeks and scans annually. Jennifer

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2012 03:52PM JeninMichigan wrote: Hi Deeze.  Welcome.    I was on Tykerb several years ago and had the rash mostly on my arms.   I noticed over the year I took it that it was for me the heat versus the sun that made it worse.    Hot baths/showers or the sun made it more pronounced.    Split fingertips and nails where just awful.  Watch your toes.  Try to cut your toenails straight across and keep them moisturized.  I had to have two ingrown nails removed ... OUCH!!!    Bag Balm or crack creak for your hands and feet.    You might be able to have your dose decreased which might helped.   I know during the course of the year I went from 1250 to 1000 and the last few months stayed at 750 mgs.   Good luck.  I hope you can find a way to ease these side effects. Tykerb is a great drug. Jennifer
Posts.Title: Tykerb-Evil Rash Deeze tooyoungtohavebc

Posts.Content: May 20, 2010 08:04AM JeninMichigan wrote: Janis I  was on Tykerb for one year.   I messed around with different times taking the pills and for me the best time was in the evening ....like around 8:00.    I was on 1000 mg and towards the end of the year was reduced to 750 mg.    I had the trots really bad the morning after taking the first pills.  I was like OMG ... is this what it is going to be like.  Took the immodium but called my naturalist.   I increased the amount of one of the supplements I take and the diarrhea went away nearly immediately.  I would say I went to the bathroom far more than I do now but it wasn't diarrhea but going 3-4 times a day is alot.     I didn't get the rash until about 4 months into treatment.  I got it mostly on my arms.   It would show up within an hour of taking it and then be very faded by the next morning.... another good reason to take it at night.   Finger tip splitting and nail issues was my chief compliant.   I have been off it now for 5 months and am just finally starting to get a tiny bit of fingernail going .    It really isn't intolerable.   I thinking getting some hints on what to do for the couple side effects in advance is a good thing.    I would buy bag balm (go to your local farm store ... like TSC) and put it on at night and cover your fingers.    Those splits hurt like hell and when you skin is dry it is near impossible to get them to heal.  Wishing you lots of luck!!! Jennifer

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2010 09:48AM JeninMichigan wrote: I too am sorry to hear about your mom's second diagnosis.    Please try not to focus on statistics and survival rates.    My oncologist would absolutely not quote statistics.  She reminded me that breast cancer is made up of so many variations it is like 15 diseases in itself.  Comparing HER+ with ER+ can be like comparing heart disease to diabetis.  The published statistics are a combination of everything that falls under breast cancer.   And they are not current.  The treatments are advanced quicker than they can keep up with statistics.  So, my advise is not to go there.   Make sure you are and your mom are confident in your oncologist and cancer center.  make sure you understand the drugs and their side effects.   Stage IV is being seen more and more like a chronic disease and it is treatable.  No there is no cure but in my mind even the early stages of this cancer there is no cure.  The fear of it returning is forever there.    Jennifer

Posts.Content: Dec 7, 2011 11:09AM JeninMichigan wrote: I think you should do what you find the most pleasure in and are able to do.    If you enjoy working and are able to swing it with your treatment, then you shouldn't give it up.   If work is a struggle and you are able to get by without doing it, then consider the options of not working.   I have been stage IV now coming up on four years.  I have worked full time throughout but I HAVE to do it.  I am a single mom and need to carry insurance.    However, even though I HAVE to work, I am not sure I would give it up.    Regarding taking this easy ... I think you need to go with what your body is telling you.    If you are exhausted at night, it might be a clue.  My larger concern is stress.  Does work mostly stress you out or mostly give you pleasure and maybe a good diversion from the disease?   Just my opinion, but I live like I am living .. not like I am dying.  After I got all my final wishes in order, I put that behind me and most days I try really hard to live like a normal person.   If you are going to give up your job, just make sure you have activities and interest that give you happiness and value.    I know of a few ladies on board who stopped working and their lives are very complete.  They have little ones though and are quite consumed.    Some have volunteered.   It is totally a personal decision. Clear as mud ... right?? Jennifer

Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2010 06:43PM JeninMichigan wrote: Kelly I am sorry for your friend's diagnosis. Simply put, being stage IV means the cancer has spread to an organ(s) and/or bones.   It means it is not curable.   However, it is treatable and many women live with this disease for many years.  It is not the end all.    Especially being ER pos and Her 2 pos there are many treatment options.  The reality is that it is a chronic disease and she will likely be in some sort of treatment for the rest of her life.    I am slightly ER + and Her2+ and the last 1 1/2 have been a very good normal life for me.    You may want to direct her to this sight as it is a wonderful source of information and support.  You are welcome here as well. Jennifer

Posts.Content: Apr 28, 2014 11:45AM JeninMichigan wrote: I can't speak for the masses but I think many of us with MBC wish that a celeb would use their diagnosis as a tool to correctly educate.   I can appreciate it is personal for her too but if you are going to talk about it then at least present it correctly.   This is the difference between earlier stage and stage IV.   I was only early stage for a few weeks before my stage IV but I lived and breathed that 95 percent 5 year survival rate and I took it to mean a cure rate.   I was focused on .. this is just a short time in my life I will have have to go through treatment.    I said it was going to be tough but I was tougher... all that stuff you hear.    It was until my mets were quickly found that I knew was MBC even was.   I didn't know I was no longer curable and I didn't know treatment was without end until the end.   I was so much happier in my other bubble of limited information.   It is not incumbant on Amy R. to gather all this information and report on what could be and what her future could look like.   I guess the short while I was in her shoes I didn't go searching for how many people end up getting mets.    I recall recently posting some facts on information on a Komen Facebook page and was met with responses about .."thanks for ruining my day" and "I didn't near to hear this".    But it needs to be heard and we all wish someone would step up away from the happy pink tidalwave of be tough and win and say what happens in the day and shorter life of a MBC patient.  To that exact point is why we carve off the Stage IV section as it is hard for others to appreciate and respect treatment for life as it is hard for us to look at someone going through treatment for breast cancer who is celebrating the end of their treatment.  When it is the end of our treatment ... it is not an event we cheer about.   I am OK with all stages posting here especially as it relates to offering support or often some expertise.  However, you can't really understand how badly we want someone in the public eye to stand up and say "look it isn't all pink and happy with breast cancer.   Women suffer.  This sh#t ruins your life in so many ways.  And, it is not curable and it does come back 20-30 percent of the time with early stage b/c and when it does, it kills you but not before you spend whatever time you have left constantly in treatment".   We want it known.  There is no ill will towards Amy R.  We just wish she wouldn't brush over it.  We wish she would have instead of saying early detection saves lives that she would have said .. in 70 percent of the cases, it saves lives.     Jen

Posts.Content: Dec 4, 2012 06:52AM JeninMichigan wrote: I had been divorced for 3 years when breast cancer came along.   I was just getting to the point of thinking about casually dating and in fact had met a guy.   I ditched him when I got my diagnosis.   The following year after finishing up chemo, he was calling me again and I went out with him.    Very self conscious about being bald and having a port and a slightly disfigured breast, but he didn't care about any of it.  In fact, when my hair was super short, I was completely ok ditcing the wig with him.   However, the closer he got, the more I pushed away and it just wasn't "it" for me.  However, lesson learned was that someone could accept me in my broken state and that alone was great for my self esteem.   I met another guy online about last year this time and I told him on the second date and he also didn't care at all.  I didn't like him either.   Then I gave up and met a high school friend at a gathering and have been dating him since February last year    It can happen and apparently there are some guys who don't care.   When telling them, I just said I have to share something with you about myself.   I think it is just a part of sharing information about who you are when you are meeting someone ... like your past and interests and other things you talk about when you are getting to know each other a little better .. but not at the beginning.  Good luck and have some fun.  Dating is not for the thin skinned though.  Regardless of cancer, there is rejection and it goes both ways.  Entering it lightly and with the intention on having some fun is a good way to approach it. Jennifer

Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2010 09:54PM JeninMichigan wrote: Andrea I am so sorry your mom is back at in treatment again.  I am also her2+ and had liver mets.    I have been lucky that mine continue to respond to Herceptin.  It sounds like they pulled your mom off Herceptin?    I would ask your mom's oncologist about clinical trials using TDM1 which is a newer drug for Her2+.   Also maybe she can do a combination of Taxol or Taxotere with Herceptin.  Sometimes it seems like after a long period of time, the Herceptin needs a boost from a chemo drug to start working its magic again.   Take heart that she has responded previously and that there are still combinations out there to try for her.    I don't think you are at the end of treatment options for your mom at all.     Do a search on Her2+ clinical trials and bring that information wtih you to your appointment.  Please keep us posted. (((hugs)))) Jennifer

Posts.Content: Oct 26, 2014 08:28AM JeninMichigan wrote: good replies Rosevalley and Fitz.  I have two daughters and my mom who have panic attacks and general anxiety.   The one thing I have learned is when it happens there is no reasoning with yourself.  Trying to maintain a state of thinking that keeps you relaxed helps in preventing panic attacks. Meditating and yoga are great tools. Music is very helpful too.   I fought the idea of giving my youngest meds but finally quality of her life was taking a hit with the anxiety and a lose dose of Prozac has changed her life.   The emotional and mental toll of cancer is huge and sometimes this is one area our docs miss in treatment.  Anxiety is taxing on your body and good for you addressing it.  Don't be afraid to get help through meds.     Jen

Posts.Content: Aug 31, 2009 10:52PM JeninMichigan wrote: I am sorry your pet scan came back showing mets!!   I would suspect your oncologist might want you to have a biopsy (probably of the lung) to confirm the pet and also make sure the pathology is the same as your original b/c.    The path report will in part determine the treatment.    If you were ER + before ... you will need to see if you are still ER+ or if your Her2 status has changed.   Lots of treatment options are out there.   I have liver/bone mets and have been NED (no evidence of disease) for about 15 months now.    Good luck at your appointment!! Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2012 07:38AM JeninMichigan wrote: Kaelia I am sorry your date didn't turn out to be all you expected.  I relate dating to looking for a house.   In the ad the house sounds great.  For some, when you drive by the house (or personally meet the guy), it falls well short of the ad.   Then others look good on the outside too but once you get inside you find things have not been kept up real well.    So, cross that one off the list and continue on your search.   I thought I found a real keeper but after dating him for almost a year now, I am getting ready to bail.   He wanted to get married and it really scared me.   Part of me thinks I should be happy to have found a really nice man who loves me and most importantly is not stopped by my disease but it is not "the one" and regardless if I have cancer, I want "the one".    You should too.   In the meantime, have fun going out and laugh off the ones that didn't turn out.     I don't have any outrageous dating stories but my girlfriends have told me lots of funny ones.   Just be safe and have fun.   Jennifer

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2013 11:04AM JeninMichigan wrote: I so agree.  October stresses me out.  I recently went to a fundraiser on behalf of a dear friend who had passed and Komen was there.  The MC for the night made mention about Komen and said that early detection and prevention are the cure.    I almost chocked my drink out of my nose.  Seriously??   I did not hear this, did I?     I was pissed off all night long.   Finally I approached the MC and said, "Look you knew Gretchen was diagnosed at 33 years old - Stage 2a right?  She recurred 37 years old - stage b - other side.   She recurred again at 42 years old with liver mets.  She miraculously was NED for 5 years and recurred again with lung mets at 47 and passed four months later.   Where was her cure in early detection?    Mammograms miss it every day and every day cancer victims miss their mammograms either because they are too young or not covered.   My mammogram and ultrasound missed mine even when everyone could feel the lump.  I was Stage IV right at the start at age 41.    Prevention ... what does that mean?  How are we to prevent breast cancer???   I don't understand that at all".   She totally blew me off and said that Komen has done wonderful things for breast cancer and it was a fund Gretchen supported and so know Gretchen's fund will continue to support it.   ugggghhh... I left early because I felt like I was going to make a scene. People do not want to hear the ugly truth.  They want to believe that breast cancer is totally a curable disease and that we are all making strides in breast cancer.  Certainly anyone who is Stage IV didn't get checked early enough and that is why their cancer is advanced.  Or maybe we did something else to cause our cancer like drank alcohol or ate too much sugar or are too fat or had kids too late, or too early or didn't breastfeed or WHATEVER!   Really I hate breast cancer awareness..... Jennifer
